       </tr>
      </table>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Before_895">
        Before 895
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hungary&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Before 895">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_prehistory" title="Hungarian prehistory">
        Hungarian prehistory
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_mythology" title="Hungarian mythology">
        Hungarian mythology
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Hungarian_warrior.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="552" data-file-width="734" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cf/Hungarian_warrior.jpg/220px-Hungarian_warrior.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cf/Hungarian_warrior.jpg/330px-Hungarian_warrior.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cf/Hungarian_warrior.jpg/440px-Hungarian_warrior.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Hungarian_warrior.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Italian fresco depicting a Hungarian warrior shooting backwards
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">
        Roman Empire
       </a>
       conquered the territory west of the
       <a href="/wiki/Danube" title="Danube">
        Danube
       </a>
       between 35 and 9 BC. From 9 BC to the end of the 4th century,
       <a href="/wiki/Pannonia" title="Pannonia">
        Pannonia
       </a>
       was part of the Roman Empire, located within part of later Hungary's territory. Here, a 600-strong Roman legion created the settlement
       <a href="/wiki/Aquincum" title="Aquincum">
        Aquincum
       </a>
       in AD 41–54. A civil city grew gradually in the neighborhood of the military settlement, and in AD 106 Aquincum became the focal point of the commercial life of this area and the capital city of the Pannonian Inferior region. This area now corresponds to the
       <a href="/wiki/%C3%93buda" title="Óbuda">
        Óbuda
       </a>
       district of Budapest, with the Roman ruins now forming part of the modern Aquincum museum.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-52">
        <a href="#cite_note-52">
         [52]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Later came the
       <a href="/wiki/Huns" title="Huns">
        Huns
       </a>
       , who built a powerful empire. After Hunnish rule, the Germanic
       <a href="/wiki/Ostrogoths" title="Ostrogoths">
        Ostrogoths
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Lombards" title="Lombards">
        Lombards
       </a>
       , and Gepids, and the
       <a href="/wiki/Polyethnicity" title="Polyethnicity">
        polyethnic
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Avar_Khaganate" title="Avar Khaganate">
        Avars
       </a>
       , had a presence in the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Carpathian_Basin" title="Carpathian Basin">
        Carpathian Basin
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-53">
        <a href="#cite_note-53">
         [53]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In the 9th century,
       <a href="/wiki/East_Francia" title="East Francia">
        East Francia
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/First_Bulgarian_Empire" title="First Bulgarian Empire">
        First Bulgarian Empire
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Great_Moravia" title="Great Moravia">
        Great Moravia
       </a>
       ruled the territory of the Carpathian Basin. The land was inhabited mainly by
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Avars_(Carpathians)" title="Avars (Carpathians)">
        Avars
       </a>
       . The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Magyars" title="Magyars">
        Magyars
       </a>
       advancing through the Carpathian Basin encountered the Hungarian-speaking
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sz%C3%A9kely" title="Székely">
        Székely
       </a>
       people who inhabited the land at that time.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-54">
        <a href="#cite_note-54">
         [54]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Both contemporary sources
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-55">
        <a href="#cite_note-55">
         [55]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-A_Country_Study:_Hungary_56-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-A_Country_Study:_Hungary-56">
         [56]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and a growing amount of archaeological evidence suggests that groups of the Avars survived the disintegration of their empire.
      </p>
      <p>
       The freshly unified
       <a href="/wiki/Magyar_tribes" title="Magyar tribes">
        Hungarians
       </a>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-57">
        <a href="#cite_note-57">
         [57]
        </a>
       </sup>
       led by
       <a href="/wiki/%C3%81rp%C3%A1d" title="Árpád">
        Árpád
       </a>
       settled in the Carpathian Basin starting in 895.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-A_Country_Study:_Hungary_56-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-A_Country_Study:_Hungary-56">
         [56]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Eliznik.org.uk_58-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Eliznik.org.uk-58">
         [58]
        </a>
       </sup>
       According to linguistic evidence, they originated from an ancient
       <a href="/wiki/Uralic_languages" title="Uralic languages">
        Uralic
       </a>
       -speaking population that formerly inhabited the forested area between the
       <a href="/wiki/Volga_River" title="Volga River">
        Volga River
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/Ural_Mountains" title="Ural Mountains">
        Ural Mountains
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-59">
        <a href="#cite_note-59">
         [59]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span id="Medieval_Hungary_895.E2.80.931526">
       </span>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Medieval_Hungary_895–1526">
        Medieval Hungary 895–1526
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hungary&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Medieval Hungary 895–1526">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/Principality_of_Hungary" title="Principality of Hungary">
        Principality of Hungary
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Hungary_in_the_Middle_Ages" title="Kingdom of Hungary in the Middle Ages">
        Kingdom of Hungary in the Middle Ages
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:242px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Kalandozasok.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="496" data-file-width="724" height="164" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Kalandozasok.jpg/240px-Kalandozasok.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Kalandozasok.jpg/360px-Kalandozasok.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Kalandozasok.jpg/480px-Kalandozasok.jpg 2x" width="240"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Kalandozasok.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_invasions_of_Europe" title="Hungarian invasions of Europe">
          Hungarian raids in the 10th century
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       As a federation of united tribes,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hungarian_Conquest_of_the_Carpathian_Basin" title="Hungarian Conquest of the Carpathian Basin">
        Hungary was established in 895
       </a>
       , some 50 years after the division of the
       <a href="/wiki/Carolingian_Empire" title="Carolingian Empire">
        Carolingian Empire
       </a>
       at the
       <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Verdun" title="Treaty of Verdun">
        Treaty of Verdun
       </a>
       in 843, before the unification of the
       <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_England" title="Kingdom of England">
        Anglo-Saxon kingdoms
       </a>
       . Initially, the rising
       <a href="/wiki/Principality_of_Hungary" title="Principality of Hungary">
        Principality of Hungary
       </a>
       ("Western Tourkia" in medieval Greek sources)
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-60">
        <a href="#cite_note-60">
         [60]
        </a>
       </sup>
       was a state consisting of a semi-nomadic people. It accomplished an enormous transformation into a Christian realm during the 10th century.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Stephen_Wyley_61-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Stephen_Wyley-61">
         [61]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       This state was well-functioning and the nation's military power allowed the Hungarians to conduct successful
       <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_invasions_of_Europe" title="Hungarian invasions of Europe">
        fierce campaigns and raids
       </a>
       from
       <a href="/wiki/Constantinople" title="Constantinople">
        Constantinople
       </a>
       to as far as today's Spain.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Stephen_Wyley_61-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Stephen_Wyley-61">
         [61]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The Hungarians
       <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_invasions_of_Europe" title="Hungarian invasions of Europe">
        defeated no fewer than three major East Frankish Imperial Armies
       </a>
       between 907 and 910.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-62">
        <a href="#cite_note-62">
         [62]
        </a>
       </sup>
       A later defeat at the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Battle_of_Lechfeld" title="Battle of Lechfeld">
        Battle of Lechfeld
       </a>
       in 955 signaled a provisory end to most campaigns on foreign territories, at least towards the West.
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span id="Age_of_.C3.81rp.C3.A1dian_kings">
       </span>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Age_of_Árpádian_kings">
        Age of Árpádian kings
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hungary&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: Age of Árpádian kings">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/%C3%81rp%C3%A1d_dynasty" title="Árpád dynasty">
        Árpád dynasty
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Istvan-ChroniconPictum.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="768" data-file-width="823" height="159" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/Istvan-ChroniconPictum.jpg/170px-Istvan-ChroniconPictum.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/Istvan-ChroniconPictum.jpg/255px-Istvan-ChroniconPictum.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/Istvan-ChroniconPictum.jpg/340px-Istvan-ChroniconPictum.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Istvan-ChroniconPictum.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         King
         <a href="/wiki/Stephen_I_of_Hungary" title="Stephen I of Hungary">
          Saint Stephen
         </a>
         , the first
         <a href="/wiki/King_of_Hungary" title="King of Hungary">
          King of Hungary
         </a>
         , converted the nation to Christianity
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:A_Szent_Korona_el%C3%B6lr%C5%91l_2.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1750" data-file-width="1500" height="198" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/A_Szent_Korona_el%C3%B6lr%C5%91l_2.jpg/170px-A_Szent_Korona_el%C3%B6lr%C5%91l_2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/A_Szent_Korona_el%C3%B6lr%C5%91l_2.jpg/255px-A_Szent_Korona_el%C3%B6lr%C5%91l_2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/A_Szent_Korona_el%C3%B6lr%C5%91l_2.jpg/340px-A_Szent_Korona_el%C3%B6lr%C5%91l_2.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:A_Szent_Korona_el%C3%B6lr%C5%91l_2.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The
         <a href="/wiki/Holy_Crown_of_Hungary" title="Holy Crown of Hungary">
          Holy Crown
         </a>
         (
         <i>
          Szent Korona
         </i>
         ), one of the key symbols of Hungary
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The year 972 marked the date when the ruling prince (
       <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_language" title="Hungarian language">
        Hungarian
       </a>
       :
       <i>
        <span lang="hu">
         fejedelem
        </span>
       </i>
       )
       <a href="/wiki/G%C3%A9za,_Grand_Prince_of_the_Hungarians" title="Géza, Grand Prince of the Hungarians">
        Géza
       </a>
       of the
       <a href="/wiki/%C3%81rp%C3%A1d_dynasty" title="Árpád dynasty">
        Árpád dynasty
       </a>
       officially started to integrate Hungary into the Christian Western Europe.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-63">
        <a href="#cite_note-63">
         [63]
        </a>
       </sup>
       His first-born son,
       <a href="/wiki/Stephen_I_of_Hungary" title="Stephen I of Hungary">
        Saint Stephen I
       </a>
       , became the first
       <a href="/wiki/King_of_Hungary" title="King of Hungary">
        King of Hungary
       </a>
       after defeating his
       <a href="/wiki/Paganism" title="Paganism">
        pagan
       </a>
       uncle
       <a href="/wiki/Kopp%C3%A1ny" title="Koppány">
        Koppány
       </a>
       , who also claimed the throne. Under Stephen, Hungary was recognized as a Catholic
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Apostolic_Kingdom" title="Apostolic Kingdom">
        Apostolic Kingdom
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-64">
        <a href="#cite_note-64">
         [64]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Applying to
       <a href="/wiki/Pope_Sylvester_II" title="Pope Sylvester II">
        Pope Sylvester II
       </a>
       , Stephen received the insignia of royalty (including probably a part of the
       <a href="/wiki/Holy_Crown_of_Hungary" title="Holy Crown of Hungary">
        Holy Crown of Hungary
       </a>
       , currently kept in the
       <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_Parliament_Building" title="Hungarian Parliament Building">
        Hungarian Parliament
       </a>
       ) from the papacy.
      </p>
      <p>
       By 1006, Stephen had consolidated his power, and started sweeping reforms to convert Hungary into a Western
       <a href="/wiki/Feudalism" title="Feudalism">
        feudal state
       </a>
       . The country switched to using the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Latin_language" title="Latin language">
        Latin language
       </a>
       , and until as late as 1844, Latin remained the official language of Hungary. Hungary became a powerful kingdom.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-65">
        <a href="#cite_note-65">
         [65]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Ladislaus_I_of_Hungary" title="Ladislaus I of Hungary">
        Ladislaus I
       </a>
       extended Hungary's frontier in Transylvania and invaded
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Croatia_(medieval)" title="Kingdom of Croatia (medieval)">
        Croatia
       </a>
       in 1091.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-66">
        <a href="#cite_note-66">
         [66]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-67">
        <a href="#cite_note-67">
         [67]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-68">
        <a href="#cite_note-68">
         [68]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-69">
        <a href="#cite_note-69">
         [69]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The Croatian campaign culminated in the
       <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Gvozd_Mountain" title="Battle of Gvozd Mountain">
        Battle of Gvozd Mountain
       </a>
       in 1097 and a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Croatia_in_personal_union_with_Hungary" title="Croatia in personal union with Hungary">
        personal union of Croatia and Hungary
       </a>
       in 1102, ruled by
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Coloman_of_Hungary" title="Coloman of Hungary">
        Coloman
       </a>
       i.e. Könyves Kálmán.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HR-HU-Heka_70-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-HR-HU-Heka-70">
         [70]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:King_St._Ladislaus.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1221" data-file-width="936" height="222" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/King_St._Ladislaus.jpg/170px-King_St._Ladislaus.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/King_St._Ladislaus.jpg/255px-King_St._Ladislaus.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/King_St._Ladislaus.jpg/340px-King_St._Ladislaus.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:King_St._Ladislaus.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         King
         <a href="/wiki/Ladislaus_I_of_Hungary" title="Ladislaus I of Hungary">
          Saint Ladislaus I
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The most powerful and wealthiest king of the Árpád dynasty was
       <a href="/wiki/B%C3%A9la_III_of_Hungary" title="Béla III of Hungary">
        Béla III
       </a>
       , who disposed of the equivalent of 23 tonnes of pure silver a year. This exceeded the income of the French king (estimated at 17 tonnes) and was double the receipts of the English Crown.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-71">
        <a href="#cite_note-71">
         [71]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Andrew_II_of_Hungary" title="Andrew II of Hungary">
        Andrew II
       </a>
       issued the
       <a href="/wiki/Diploma_Andreanum" title="Diploma Andreanum">
        Diploma Andreanum
       </a>
       which secured the special privileges of the
       <a href="/wiki/Transylvanian_Saxons" title="Transylvanian Saxons">
        Transylvanian Saxons
       </a>
       and is considered the first
       <a href="/wiki/Autonomy" title="Autonomy">
        Autonomy
       </a>
       law in the world.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-72">
        <a href="#cite_note-72">
         [72]
        </a>
       </sup>
       He led the
       <a href="/wiki/Fifth_Crusade" title="Fifth Crusade">
        Fifth Crusade
       </a>
       to the
       <a href="/wiki/Holy_Land" title="Holy Land">
        Holy Land
       </a>
       in 1217, setting up the largest royal army in the history of Crusades. His
       <a href="/wiki/Golden_Bull_of_1222" title="Golden Bull of 1222">
        Golden Bull of 1222
       </a>
       was the first constitution in
       <a href="/wiki/Continental_Europe" title="Continental Europe">
        Continental Europe
       </a>
       . The lesser nobles also began to present Andrew with grievances, a practice that evolved into the institution of the parliament (
       <i>
        parlamentum publicum
       </i>
       ).
      </p>
      <p>
       In 1241–1242, the kingdom received a major blow with the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mongolian_invasion_of_Hungary" title="Mongolian invasion of Hungary">
        Mongol (Tatar) Invasion
       </a>
       . Up to half of Hungary's then population of 2,000,000 were victims of the invasion.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-73">
        <a href="#cite_note-73">
         [73]
        </a>
       </sup>
       King Béla IV let
       <a href="/wiki/Cumans" title="Cumans">
        Cumans
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jassic_people" title="Jassic people">
        Jassic people
       </a>
       into the country, who were fleeing the Mongols.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-74">
        <a href="#cite_note-74">
         [74]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Over the centuries, they were fully assimilated into the Hungarian population.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-75">
        <a href="#cite_note-75">
         [75]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       As a consequence, after the Mongols retreated, King Béla ordered the construction of hundreds of stone castles and fortifications, to defend against a possible second Mongol invasion. The Mongols returned to Hungary in 1285, but the newly built stone-castle systems and new tactics (using a higher proportion of heavily armed knights) stopped them. The invading Mongol force was defeated
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-76">
        <a href="#cite_note-76">
         [76]
        </a>
       </sup>
       near Pest by the royal army of Ladislaus IV of Hungary. As with later invasions, it was repelled handily, the Mongols losing much of their invading force.
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Age_of_elected_kings">
        Age of elected kings
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hungary&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: Age of elected kings">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ottoman%E2%80%93Hungarian_Wars" title="Ottoman–Hungarian Wars">
        Ottoman–Hungarian Wars
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:242px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Louis%27s_kingdoms_and_his_vassal_territories.png">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1120" data-file-width="1817" height="148" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Louis%27s_kingdoms_and_his_vassal_territories.png/240px-Louis%27s_kingdoms_and_his_vassal_territories.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Louis%27s_kingdoms_and_his_vassal_territories.png/360px-Louis%27s_kingdoms_and_his_vassal_territories.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Louis%27s_kingdoms_and_his_vassal_territories.png/480px-Louis%27s_kingdoms_and_his_vassal_territories.png 2x" width="240"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Louis%27s_kingdoms_and_his_vassal_territories.png" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         A map of lands ruled by
         <a href="/wiki/Louis_I_of_Hungary" title="Louis I of Hungary">
          Louis the Great
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:The_wars_of_Matthias_Corvinus_of_Hungary_(1458-1490).png">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1707" data-file-width="1700" height="221" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/The_wars_of_Matthias_Corvinus_of_Hungary_%281458-1490%29.png/220px-The_wars_of_Matthias_Corvinus_of_Hungary_%281458-1490%29.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/The_wars_of_Matthias_Corvinus_of_Hungary_%281458-1490%29.png/330px-The_wars_of_Matthias_Corvinus_of_Hungary_%281458-1490%29.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/The_wars_of_Matthias_Corvinus_of_Hungary_%281458-1490%29.png/440px-The_wars_of_Matthias_Corvinus_of_Hungary_%281458-1490%29.png 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:The_wars_of_Matthias_Corvinus_of_Hungary_(1458-1490).png" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Western conquests of
         <a href="/wiki/Matthias_Corvinus" title="Matthias Corvinus">
          Matthias Corvinus
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Castelul.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3387" data-file-width="5080" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Castelul.jpg/220px-Castelul.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Castelul.jpg/330px-Castelul.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Castelul.jpg/440px-Castelul.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Castelul.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The Gothic-Renaissance
         <a href="/wiki/Corvin_Castle" title="Corvin Castle">
          Corvin Castle
         </a>
         in
         <a href="/wiki/Transylvania" title="Transylvania">
          Transylvania
         </a>
         (now Romania), built by
         <a href="/wiki/John_Hunyadi" title="John Hunyadi">
          John Hunyadi
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Hungary" title="Kingdom of Hungary">
        Kingdom of Hungary
       </a>
       reached one of its greatest extents during the Árpádian kings, yet royal power was weakened at the end of their rule in 1301. After a destructive period of
       <a href="/wiki/Interregnum" title="Interregnum">
        interregnum
       </a>
       (1301–1308), the first
       <a href="/wiki/Capetian_House_of_Anjou" title="Capetian House of Anjou">
        Angevin
       </a>
       king,
       <a href="/wiki/Charles_I_of_Hungary" title="Charles I of Hungary">
        Charles I of Hungary
       </a>
       – a bilineal descendant of the Árpád dynasty – successfully restored royal power, and defeated oligarch rivals, the so-called "little kings". The second Angevin Hungarian king,
       <a href="/wiki/Louis_I_of_Hungary" title="Louis I of Hungary">
        Louis the Great
       </a>
       (1342–1382), led many successful military campaigns from Lithuania to Southern Italy (Kingdom of Naples), and was also
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/King_of_Poland" title="King of Poland">
        King of Poland
       </a>
       from 1370. After King Louis died without a male heir, the country was stabilized only when
       <a href="/wiki/Sigismund,_Holy_Roman_Emperor" title="Sigismund, Holy Roman Emperor">
        Sigismund of Luxembourg
       </a>
       (1387–1437) succeeded to the throne, who in 1433 also became
       <a href="/wiki/Holy_Roman_Emperor" title="Holy Roman Emperor">
        Holy Roman Emperor
       </a>
       . Sigismund was also (in several ways) a bilineal descendant of the Árpád dynasty.
      </p>
      <p>
       The first Hungarian
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bible_translation" title="Bible translation">
        Bible translation
       </a>
       was completed in 1439. For half a year in 1437, there was an antifeudal and anticlerical peasant revolt in
       <a href="/wiki/Transylvania" title="Transylvania">
        Transylvania
       </a>
       , the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Budai_Nagy_Antal_Revolt" title="Budai Nagy Antal Revolt">
        Budai Nagy Antal Revolt
       </a>
       , which was strongly influenced by
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hussite" title="Hussite">
        Hussite
       </a>
       ideas.
      </p>
      <p>
       From a small noble family in Transylvania,
       <a href="/wiki/John_Hunyadi" title="John Hunyadi">
        John Hunyadi
       </a>
       grew to become one of the country's most powerful lords, thanks to his outstanding capabilities as a mercenary commander. He was elected governor then regent. He was a successful crusader against the Ottoman Turks, one of his greatest victories being the
       <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Belgrade_(1456)" title="Siege of Belgrade (1456)">
        Siege of Belgrade
       </a>
       in 1456.
      </p>
      <p>
       The last strong king of medieval Hungary was the Renaissance king
       <a href="/wiki/Matthias_Corvinus" title="Matthias Corvinus">
        Matthias Corvinus
       </a>
       (1458–1490), son of John Hunyadi. His election was the first time that a member of the nobility mounted to the Hungarian royal throne without dynastic background. He was a successful military leader and an enlightened patron of the arts and learning.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-britannica1_77-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-britannica1-77">
         [77]
        </a>
       </sup>
       His library, the Bibliotheca Corviniana, was Europe's greatest collection of historical chronicles, philosophic and scientific works in the 15th century, and second only in size to the
       <a href="/wiki/Vatican_Library" title="Vatican Library">
        Vatican Library
       </a>
       . The library is a UNESCO
       <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">
        World Heritage Site
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-78">
        <a href="#cite_note-78">
         [78]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The serfs and common people considered him a just ruler because he protected them from excessive demands from and other abuses by the magnates.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-79">
        <a href="#cite_note-79">
         [79]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Under his rule, in 1479, the Hungarian army destroyed the Ottoman and Wallachian troops at the
       <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Breadfield" title="Battle of Breadfield">
        Battle of Breadfield
       </a>
       . Abroad he defeated the Polish and German imperial armies of Frederick at Breslau (
       <a href="/wiki/Wroc%C5%82aw" title="Wrocław">
        Wrocław
       </a>
       ). Matthias' mercenary standing army, the
       <a href="/wiki/Black_Army_of_Hungary" title="Black Army of Hungary">
        Black Army of Hungary
       </a>
       , was an unusually large army for its time, and it conquered parts of Austria, Vienna (1485) and parts of
       <a href="/wiki/Bohemia" title="Bohemia">
        Bohemia
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span id="Decline_of_Hungary_.281490.E2.80.931526.29">
       </span>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Decline_of_Hungary_(1490–1526)">
        Decline of Hungary (1490–1526)
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hungary&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: Decline of Hungary (1490–1526)">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       King Matthias died without lawful sons, and the Hungarian magnates procured the accession of the Pole
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vladislaus_II_of_Bohemia_and_Hungary" title="Vladislaus II of Bohemia and Hungary">
        Vladislaus II
       </a>
       (1490–1516), supposedly because of his weak influence on Hungarian aristocracy.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-britannica1_77-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-britannica1-77">
         [77]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Hungary's international role declined, its political stability shaken, and social progress was deadlocked.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-80">
        <a href="#cite_note-80">
         [80]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 1514, the weakened old King Vladislaus II faced a major peasant rebellion led by
       <a href="/wiki/Gy%C3%B6rgy_D%C3%B3zsa" title="György Dózsa">
        György Dózsa
       </a>
       , which was ruthlessly crushed by the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nobility_in_the_Kingdom_of_Hungary" title="Nobility in the Kingdom of Hungary">
        nobles
       </a>
       , led by
       <a href="/wiki/John_Z%C3%A1polya" title="John Zápolya">
        John Zápolya
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       The resulting degradation of order paved the way for Ottoman pre-eminence. In 1521, the strongest Hungarian fortress in the South, Nándorfehérvár (today's
       <a href="/wiki/Belgrade" title="Belgrade">
        Belgrade
       </a>
       , Serbia),
       <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Belgrade_(1521)" title="Siege of Belgrade (1521)">
        fell to the Turks
       </a>
       . The early appearance of Protestantism further worsened internal relations in the country.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span id="Ottoman_wars_1526.E2.80.931699">
       </span>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Ottoman_wars_1526–1699">
        Ottoman wars 1526–1699
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hungary&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: Ottoman wars 1526–1699">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Hungary_(1526%E2%80%931867)" title="Kingdom of Hungary (1526–1867)">
        Kingdom of Hungary (1526–1867)
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Hungary" title="Ottoman Hungary">
        Ottoman Hungary
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Principality_of_Transylvania_(1570%E2%80%931711)" title="Principality of Transylvania (1570–1711)">
        Principality of Transylvania (1570–1711)
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Ottoman%E2%80%93Habsburg_wars" title="Ottoman–Habsburg wars">
        Ottoman–Habsburg wars
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Sz%C3%A9kely,_Bertalan_-_The_Women_of_Eger_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2437" data-file-width="1884" height="220" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Sz%C3%A9kely%2C_Bertalan_-_The_Women_of_Eger_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/170px-Sz%C3%A9kely%2C_Bertalan_-_The_Women_of_Eger_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Sz%C3%A9kely%2C_Bertalan_-_The_Women_of_Eger_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/255px-Sz%C3%A9kely%2C_Bertalan_-_The_Women_of_Eger_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Sz%C3%A9kely%2C_Bertalan_-_The_Women_of_Eger_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/340px-Sz%C3%A9kely%2C_Bertalan_-_The_Women_of_Eger_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Sz%C3%A9kely,_Bertalan_-_The_Women_of_Eger_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Painting commemorating the
         <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Eger_(1552)" title="Siege of Eger (1552)">
          Siege of Eger
         </a>
         , a major victory against the Ottomans
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       After some
       <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_wars_in_Europe" title="Ottoman wars in Europe">
        150 years of wars
       </a>
       with the Hungarians and other states, the Ottomans gained a decisive victory over the Hungarian army at the
       <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Moh%C3%A1cs" title="Battle of Mohács">
        Battle of Mohács
       </a>
       in 1526, where
       <a href="/wiki/Louis_II_of_Hungary" title="Louis II of Hungary">
        King Louis II
       </a>
       died while fleeing. Amid political chaos, the divided
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nobility_in_the_Kingdom_of_Hungary" title="Nobility in the Kingdom of Hungary">
        Hungarian nobility
       </a>
       elected two kings simultaneously,
       <a href="/wiki/John_Z%C3%A1polya" title="John Zápolya">
        John Zápolya
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Ferdinand_I,_Holy_Roman_Emperor" title="Ferdinand I, Holy Roman Emperor">
        Ferdinand I
       </a>
       of the Habsburg dynasty. With the conquest of Buda by the Turks in 1541, Hungary was divided into three parts and remained so until the end of the 17th century. The north-western part, termed as
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Royal_Hungary" title="Royal Hungary">
        Royal Hungary
       </a>
       , was annexed by the Habsburgs who ruled as Kings of Hungary. The eastern part of the kingdom became independent as the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Principality_of_Transylvania_(1571%E2%80%931711)" title="Principality of Transylvania (1571–1711)">
        Principality of Transylvania
       </a>
       , under Ottoman (and later Habsburg)
       <a href="/wiki/Suzerainty" title="Suzerainty">
        suzerainty
       </a>
       . The remaining central area, including the capital Buda, was known as the
       <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Hungary" title="Ottoman Hungary">
        Pashalik of Buda
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:GaziKaszimFotoThalerTamas1.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2432" data-file-width="3648" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/GaziKaszimFotoThalerTamas1.jpg/220px-GaziKaszimFotoThalerTamas1.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/GaziKaszimFotoThalerTamas1.jpg/330px-GaziKaszimFotoThalerTamas1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/GaziKaszimFotoThalerTamas1.jpg/440px-GaziKaszimFotoThalerTamas1.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:GaziKaszimFotoThalerTamas1.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Mosque_of_Pasha_Qasim" title="Mosque of Pasha Qasim">
          Mosque of Pasha Qasim
         </a>
         in
         <a href="/wiki/P%C3%A9cs" title="Pécs">
          Pécs
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The vast majority of the seventeen and nineteen thousand Ottoman soldiers in service in the Ottoman fortresses in the territory of Hungary were Orthodox and Muslim Balkan Slavs rather than ethnic Turkish people.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-81">
        <a href="#cite_note-81">
         [81]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Orthodox Southern Slavs were also acting as
       <a href="/wiki/Akinji" title="Akinji">
        akinjis
       </a>
       and other light troops intended for pillaging in the territory of present-day Hungary.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-82">
        <a href="#cite_note-82">
         [82]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 1686, the
       <a href="/wiki/Holy_League_(1684)" title="Holy League (1684)">
        Holy League's
       </a>
       army, containing over 74,000 men from various nations,
       <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Buda_(1686)" title="Battle of Buda (1686)">
        reconquered Buda
       </a>
       from the Turks. After some more crushing
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Austro-Turkish_War_of_1716%E2%80%9318" title="Austro-Turkish War of 1716–18">
        defeats of the Ottomans
       </a>
       in the next few years, the entire Kingdom of Hungary was removed from Ottoman rule by 1718. The last raid into Hungary by the Ottoman vassals
       <a href="/wiki/Crimean_Khanate" title="Crimean Khanate">
        Tatars
       </a>
       from
       <a href="/wiki/Crimea" title="Crimea">
        Crimea
       </a>
       took place in 1717.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-83">
        <a href="#cite_note-83">
         [83]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The constrained Habsburg Counter-Reformation efforts in the 17th century reconverted the majority of the kingdom to Catholicism. The ethnic composition of Hungary was fundamentally changed as a consequence of the prolonged warfare with the Turks. A large part of the country became devastated, population growth was stunted, and many smaller settlements perished.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-84">
        <a href="#cite_note-84">
         [84]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The Austrian-Habsburg government settled large groups of Serbs and other Slavs in the depopulated south, and settled
       <a href="/wiki/Germans_of_Hungary" title="Germans of Hungary">
        Germans
       </a>
       (called
       <a href="/wiki/Danube_Swabians" title="Danube Swabians">
        Danube Swabians
       </a>
       ) in various areas, but Hungarians were not allowed to settle or re-settle in the south of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pannonian_Plain" title="Pannonian Plain">
        Great Plain
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-85">
        <a href="#cite_note-85">
         [85]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="From_the_18th_century_to_World_War_I">
        From the 18th century to World War I
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hungary&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9" title="Edit section: From the 18th century to World War I">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_Revolution_of_1848" title="Hungarian Revolution of 1848">
        Hungarian Revolution of 1848
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Austria-Hungary" title="Austria-Hungary">
        Austria-Hungary
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Lands_of_the_Crown_of_Saint_Stephen" title="Lands of the Crown of Saint Stephen">
        Lands of the Crown of Saint Stephen
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Hungary_in_World_War_I" title="Hungary in World War I">
        Hungary in World War I
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Kaiserin_Maria_Theresia_(HRR).jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2046" data-file-width="1651" height="211" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Kaiserin_Maria_Theresia_%28HRR%29.jpg/170px-Kaiserin_Maria_Theresia_%28HRR%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Kaiserin_Maria_Theresia_%28HRR%29.jpg/255px-Kaiserin_Maria_Theresia_%28HRR%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Kaiserin_Maria_Theresia_%28HRR%29.jpg/340px-Kaiserin_Maria_Theresia_%28HRR%29.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Kaiserin_Maria_Theresia_(HRR).jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Maria_Theresa" title="Maria Theresa">
          Maria Theresa
         </a>
         ruler of
         <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Hungary_(1526%E2%80%931867)" title="Kingdom of Hungary (1526–1867)">
          Kingdom of Hungary
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:M%C3%A1nyoki,_%C3%81dam_-_Portrait_of_Prince_Ferenc_R%C3%A1k%C3%B3czi_II_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3124" data-file-width="2568" height="207" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/M%C3%A1nyoki%2C_%C3%81dam_-_Portrait_of_Prince_Ferenc_R%C3%A1k%C3%B3czi_II_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/170px-M%C3%A1nyoki%2C_%C3%81dam_-_Portrait_of_Prince_Ferenc_R%C3%A1k%C3%B3czi_II_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/M%C3%A1nyoki%2C_%C3%81dam_-_Portrait_of_Prince_Ferenc_R%C3%A1k%C3%B3czi_II_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/255px-M%C3%A1nyoki%2C_%C3%81dam_-_Portrait_of_Prince_Ferenc_R%C3%A1k%C3%B3czi_II_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/M%C3%A1nyoki%2C_%C3%81dam_-_Portrait_of_Prince_Ferenc_R%C3%A1k%C3%B3czi_II_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/340px-M%C3%A1nyoki%2C_%C3%81dam_-_Portrait_of_Prince_Ferenc_R%C3%A1k%C3%B3czi_II_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:M%C3%A1nyoki,_%C3%81dam_-_Portrait_of_Prince_Ferenc_R%C3%A1k%C3%B3czi_II_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Francis_II_R%C3%A1k%C3%B3czi" title="Francis II Rákóczi">
          Francis II Rákóczi
         </a>
         , leader of the uprising against Habsburg rule in 1703–11
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Between 1703 and 1711, there was a large-scale uprising led by
       <a href="/wiki/Francis_II_R%C3%A1k%C3%B3czi" title="Francis II Rákóczi">
        Francis II Rákóczi
       </a>
       , who after the dethronement of the Habsburgs in 1707 at the Diet of
       <a href="/wiki/%C3%93nod" title="Ónod">
        Ónod
       </a>
       , took power provisionally as the Ruling Prince of Hungary for the wartime period, but refused the Hungarian Crown and the title "King". The uprisings lasted for years. After 8 years of war with the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Habsburg_Empire" title="Habsburg Empire">
        Habsburg Empire
       </a>
       , the Hungarian
       <a href="/wiki/Kuruc" title="Kuruc">
        Kuruc
       </a>
       army lost the last main
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Battle_of_Trencs%C3%A9n" title="Battle of Trencsén">
        battle at Trencsén
       </a>
       (1708).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-86">
        <a href="#cite_note-86">
         [86]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:SzechenyiIstvan1.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="856" data-file-width="606" height="240" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/SzechenyiIstvan1.jpg/170px-SzechenyiIstvan1.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/SzechenyiIstvan1.jpg/255px-SzechenyiIstvan1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/SzechenyiIstvan1.jpg/340px-SzechenyiIstvan1.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:SzechenyiIstvan1.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Count
         <a href="/wiki/Istv%C3%A1n_Sz%C3%A9chenyi" title="István Széchenyi">
          István Széchenyi
         </a>
         offered one year's income to establish the
         <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_Academy_of_Sciences" title="Hungarian Academy of Sciences">
          Hungarian Academy of Sciences
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       During the
       <a href="/wiki/Napoleonic_Wars" title="Napoleonic Wars">
        Napoleonic Wars
       </a>
       and afterwards, the Hungarian Diet had not convened for decades.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-87">
        <a href="#cite_note-87">
         [87]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In the 1820s, the Emperor was forced to convene the Diet, which marked the beginning of a Reform Period (1825–1848,
       <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_language" title="Hungarian language">
        Hungarian
       </a>
       :
       <i>
        <span lang="hu">
         reformkor
        </span>
       </i>
       ). Count
       <a href="/wiki/Istv%C3%A1n_Sz%C3%A9chenyi" title="István Széchenyi">
        István Széchenyi
       </a>
       , one of the most prominent statesmen of the country, recognized the urgent need of modernization and his message got through. The Hungarian Parliament was reconvened in 1825 to handle financial needs. A liberal party emerged and focused on providing for the peasantry.
       <a href="/wiki/Lajos_Kossuth" title="Lajos Kossuth">
        Lajos Kossuth
       </a>
       – a famous journalist at that time – emerged as leader of the lower
       <a href="/wiki/Gentry" title="Gentry">
        gentry
       </a>
       in the Parliament. A remarkable upswing started as the nation concentrated its forces on modernization even though the Habsburg monarchs obstructed all important liberal laws relating to
       <a href="/wiki/Civil_and_political_rights" title="Civil and political rights">
        civil and political rights
       </a>
       and economic reforms. Many reformers (
       <a href="/wiki/Lajos_Kossuth" title="Lajos Kossuth">
        Lajos Kossuth
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Mih%C3%A1ly_T%C3%A1ncsics" title="Mihály Táncsics">
        Mihály Táncsics
       </a>
       ) were imprisoned by the authorities.
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:E._Poulton_Portrait_of_Lajos_Kossuth_1860s.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="577" data-file-width="445" height="220" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/E._Poulton_Portrait_of_Lajos_Kossuth_1860s.jpg/170px-E._Poulton_Portrait_of_Lajos_Kossuth_1860s.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/E._Poulton_Portrait_of_Lajos_Kossuth_1860s.jpg/255px-E._Poulton_Portrait_of_Lajos_Kossuth_1860s.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/E._Poulton_Portrait_of_Lajos_Kossuth_1860s.jpg/340px-E._Poulton_Portrait_of_Lajos_Kossuth_1860s.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:E._Poulton_Portrait_of_Lajos_Kossuth_1860s.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Lajos_Kossuth" title="Lajos Kossuth">
          Lajos Kossuth
         </a>
         , Regent-President during the
         <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_Revolution_of_1848" title="Hungarian Revolution of 1848">
          Hungarian Revolution of 1848
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       On 15 March 1848, mass demonstrations in Pest and Buda enabled Hungarian reformists to push through a list of
       <a href="/wiki/12_points_of_the_Hungarian_Revolutionaries_of_1848" title="12 points of the Hungarian Revolutionaries of 1848">
        12 demands
       </a>
       . Under governor and president
       <a href="/wiki/Lajos_Kossuth" title="Lajos Kossuth">
        Lajos Kossuth
       </a>
       and the first Prime Minister,
       <a href="/wiki/Lajos_Batthy%C3%A1ny" title="Lajos Batthyány">
        Lajos Batthyány
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/House_of_Habsburg" title="House of Habsburg">
        House of Habsburg
       </a>
       was dethroned. The Habsburg Ruler and his advisors skillfully manipulated the Croatian, Serbian and Romanian peasantry, led by priests and officers firmly loyal to the Habsburgs, and induced them to rebel against the Hungarian government, though the Hungarians were supported by the vast majority of the Slovak, German and
       <a href="/wiki/Rusyns" title="Rusyns">
        Rusyn
       </a>
       nationalities and by all the Jews of the kingdom, as well as by a large number of Polish, Austrian and Italian volunteers.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-88">
        <a href="#cite_note-88">
         [88]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In July 1849 the Hungarian Parliament proclaimed and enacted the first laws of ethnic and
       <a href="/wiki/Minority_rights" title="Minority rights">
        minority rights
       </a>
       in the world.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-89">
        <a href="#cite_note-89">
         [89]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Many members of the nationalities gained the coveted highest positions within the Hungarian Army, like General
       <a href="/wiki/J%C3%A1nos_Damjanich" title="János Damjanich">
        János Damjanich
       </a>
       , an ethnic Serb who became a Hungarian national hero through his command of the 3rd Hungarian Army Corps or
       <a href="/wiki/J%C3%B3zef_Bem" title="Józef Bem">
        Józef Bem
       </a>
       , who was Polish and also became a national hero in Hungary. Initially, the Hungarian forces (
       <i>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Royal_Hungarian_Landwehr" title="Royal Hungarian Landwehr">
         Honvédség
        </a>
       </i>
       ) defeated Austrian armies. To counter the successes of the Hungarian revolutionary army, Habsburg Emperor
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Franz_Joseph_I" title="Franz Joseph I">
        Franz Joseph I
       </a>
       asked for help from the "Gendarme of Europe", Czar
       <a href="/wiki/Nicholas_I_of_Russia" title="Nicholas I of Russia">
        Nicholas I
       </a>
       , whose Russian armies invaded Hungary. This made
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Art%C3%BAr_G%C3%B6rgey" title="Artúr Görgey">
        Artúr Görgey
       </a>
       surrender in August 1849. The leader of the Austrian army,
       <a href="/wiki/Julius_Jacob_von_Haynau" title="Julius Jacob von Haynau">
        Julius Jacob von Haynau
       </a>
       , became governor of Hungary for a few months, and ordered the execution of
       <a href="/wiki/The_13_Martyrs_of_Arad" title="The 13 Martyrs of Arad">
        the 13 Martyrs of Arad
       </a>
       , leaders of the Hungarian army, and Prime Minister Batthyány in October 1849. Lajos Kossuth escaped into exile. Following the war of 1848 – 1849, the whole country was in "passive resistance".
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Cisleithania,_Lands_of_the_Crown_of_Saint_Stephen,_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina.svg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="605" data-file-width="783" height="232" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/Cisleithania%2C_Lands_of_the_Crown_of_Saint_Stephen%2C_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina.svg/300px-Cisleithania%2C_Lands_of_the_Crown_of_Saint_Stephen%2C_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/Cisleithania%2C_Lands_of_the_Crown_of_Saint_Stephen%2C_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina.svg/450px-Cisleithania%2C_Lands_of_the_Crown_of_Saint_Stephen%2C_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/Cisleithania%2C_Lands_of_the_Crown_of_Saint_Stephen%2C_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina.svg/600px-Cisleithania%2C_Lands_of_the_Crown_of_Saint_Stephen%2C_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina.svg.png 2x" width="300"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Cisleithania,_Lands_of_the_Crown_of_Saint_Stephen,_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina.svg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Territories of the Kingdom of Hungary and the Kingdom of Croatia (green parts) within the
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Austro-Hungarian_Empire" title="Austro-Hungarian Empire">
          Austro-Hungarian Empire
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Because of external and internal problems, reforms seemed inevitable and major military defeats of Austria forced the Habsburgs to negotiate the
       <a href="/wiki/Austro-Hungarian_Compromise_of_1867" title="Austro-Hungarian Compromise of 1867">
        Austro-Hungarian Compromise of 1867
       </a>
       , by which the dual Monarchy of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Austria%E2%80%93Hungary" title="Austria–Hungary">
        Austria–Hungary
       </a>
       was formed. This Empire had the second largest area in Europe (after the
       <a href="/wiki/Russian_Empire" title="Russian Empire">
        Russian Empire
       </a>
       ), and it was the third most populous (after Russia and the
       <a href="/wiki/German_Empire" title="German Empire">
        German Empire
       </a>
       ). The two realms were governed separately by two parliaments from two capital cities, with a common monarch and common external and military policies. Economically, the empire was a customs union. The old Hungarian Constitution was restored, and Franz Joseph I was crowned as
       <a href="/wiki/King_of_Hungary" title="King of Hungary">
        King of Hungary
       </a>
       . The era witnessed impressive economic development. The formerly backward Hungarian economy became relatively modern and industrialized by the turn of the 20th century, although agriculture remained dominant until 1890. In 1873, the old capital
       <a href="/wiki/Buda" title="Buda">
        Buda
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/%C3%93buda" title="Óbuda">
        Óbuda
       </a>
       were officially united with
       <a href="/wiki/Pest,_Hungary" title="Pest, Hungary">
        Pest
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-90">
        <a href="#cite_note-90">
         [90]
        </a>
       </sup>
       thus creating the new metropolis of
       <a href="/wiki/Budapest" title="Budapest">
        Budapest
       </a>
       . Many of the state institutions and the modern administrative system of Hungary were established during this period.
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Szent_Istvan.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="460" data-file-width="861" height="118" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Szent_Istvan.jpg/220px-Szent_Istvan.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Szent_Istvan.jpg/330px-Szent_Istvan.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Szent_Istvan.jpg/440px-Szent_Istvan.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Szent_Istvan.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Hungarian built
         <a href="/wiki/Dreadnought" title="Dreadnought">
          dreadnought
         </a>
         battleship
         <a href="/wiki/SMS_Szent_Istv%C3%A1n" title="SMS Szent István">
          SMS
          <i>
           Szent István
          </i>
         </a>
         in World War I
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       After the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Assassination_in_Sarajevo" title="Assassination in Sarajevo">
        Assassination in Sarajevo
       </a>
       , the Hungarian prime minister
       <a href="/wiki/Istv%C3%A1n_Tisza" title="István Tisza">
        István Tisza
       </a>
       and his cabinet tried to avoid the outbreak and escalating of a war in Europe, but their diplomatic efforts were unsuccessful.
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Austria%E2%80%93Hungary" title="Austria–Hungary">
        Austria–Hungary
       </a>
       drafted 9 million (fighting forces: 7.8 million) soldiers in World War I (over 4 million from the Kingdom of Hungary) on the side of Germany, Bulgaria and Turkey. The troops raised in the Kingdom of Hungary spent little time defending the actual territory of Hungary, with the exceptions of the
       <a href="/wiki/Brusilov_Offensive" title="Brusilov Offensive">
        Brusilov Offensive
       </a>
       in June 1916, and a few months later, when the Romanian army made an attack into Transylvania,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-91">
        <a href="#cite_note-91">
         [91]
        </a>
       </sup>
       both of which were repelled. In comparison, of the total army, Hungary's loss ratio was more than any other nations of Austria-Hungary. The
       <a href="/wiki/Central_Powers" title="Central Powers">
        Central Powers
       </a>
       conquered Serbia. Romania declared war. The Central Powers conquered Southern Romania and the Romanian capital
       <a href="/wiki/Bucharest" title="Bucharest">
        Bucharest
       </a>
       . In 1916 Emperor Franz Joseph died, and the new monarch
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Charles_IV_of_Hungary" title="Charles IV of Hungary">
        Charles IV
       </a>
       sympathized with the pacifists. With great difficulty, the Central powers stopped and repelled the attacks of the Russian Empire.
      </p>
      <p>
       The Eastern front of the Allied (
       <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_I" title="Allies of World War I">
        Entente
       </a>
       ) Powers completely collapsed. The Austro-Hungarian Empire then withdrew from all defeated countries. On the Italian front, the Austro-Hungarian army made no progress against Italy after January 1918. Despite great Eastern successes, Germany suffered complete defeat on the more important Western front. By 1918, the economic situation had deteriorated (strikes in factories were organized by leftist and pacifist movements) and uprisings in the army had become commonplace. In the capital cities, the Austrian and Hungarian leftist liberal movements (the maverick parties) and their leaders supported the separatism of ethnic minorities. Austria-Hungary signed a general armistice in
       <a href="/wiki/Padua" title="Padua">
        Padua
       </a>
       on 3 November 1918.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-92">
        <a href="#cite_note-92">
         [92]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In October 1918, Hungary's union with Austria was dissolved.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span id="Between_the_World_Wars_1918.E2.80.931941">
       </span>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Between_the_World_Wars_1918–1941">
        Between the World Wars 1918–1941
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hungary&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10" title="Edit section: Between the World Wars 1918–1941">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <table class="plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-Unreferenced" role="presentation">
       <tr>
        <td class="mbox-image">
         <div style="width:52px">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="399" data-file-width="512" height="39" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/75px-Question_book-new.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/100px-Question_book-new.svg.png 2x" width="50"/>
          </a>
         </div>
        </td>
        <td class="mbox-text">
         <div class="mbox-text-span">
          This section
          <b>
           does not
           <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources">
            cite
           </a>
           any
           <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability">
            sources
           </a>
          </b>
          .
          <span class="hide-when-compact">
           Please help
           <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Hungary&amp;action=edit">
            improve this section
           </a>
           by
           <a href="/wiki/Help:Introduction_to_referencing_with_Wiki_Markup/1" title="Help:Introduction to referencing with Wiki Markup/1">
            adding citations to reliable sources
           </a>
           . Unsourced material may be challenged and
           <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability#Burden_of_evidence" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability">

           </a>
           .
          </span>

            (October 2017)

            </a>

           </i>
          </small>
         </div>
