       </tr>
      </table>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/Hungary_between_the_World_Wars" title="Hungary between the World Wars">
        Hungary between the World Wars
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_interwar_economy" title="Hungarian interwar economy">
        Hungarian interwar economy
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Trianon_consequences.png">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="774" data-file-width="1140" height="149" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Trianon_consequences.png/220px-Trianon_consequences.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Trianon_consequences.png/330px-Trianon_consequences.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Trianon_consequences.png/440px-Trianon_consequences.png 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Trianon_consequences.png" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         With the
         <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Trianon" title="Treaty of Trianon">
          Treaty of Trianon
         </a>
         , Hungary lost 72% of its territory, its sea ports and 3,425,000 ethnic Hungarians
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-93">
          <a href="#cite_note-93">
           [93]
          </a>
         </sup>
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-94">
          <a href="#cite_note-94">
           [94]
          </a>
         </sup>
         <div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column">
          <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #cd3318; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">
          </span>
          Majority Hungarian areas (according to the 1910 census) detached from Hungary
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Portraits_de_Mikl%C3%B3s_Horthy.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1904" data-file-width="1416" height="229" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Portraits_de_Mikl%C3%B3s_Horthy.jpg/170px-Portraits_de_Mikl%C3%B3s_Horthy.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Portraits_de_Mikl%C3%B3s_Horthy.jpg/255px-Portraits_de_Mikl%C3%B3s_Horthy.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Portraits_de_Mikl%C3%B3s_Horthy.jpg/340px-Portraits_de_Mikl%C3%B3s_Horthy.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Portraits_de_Mikl%C3%B3s_Horthy.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Mikl%C3%B3s_Horthy" title="Miklós Horthy">
          Miklós Horthy
         </a>
         , Regent of the Kingdom of Hungary (1920–1944)
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Following the First World War, Hungary underwent a period of profound political upheaval, beginning with the
       <a href="/wiki/Aster_Revolution" title="Aster Revolution">
        Aster Revolution
       </a>
       in 1918, which brought the social-democratic
       <a href="/wiki/Mih%C3%A1ly_K%C3%A1rolyi" title="Mihály Károlyi">
        Mihály Károlyi
       </a>
       to power as Prime Minister. Károlyi dissolved the union with Austria and disarmed the Hungarian Army, leaving the country without any national defense. The
       <a href="/wiki/Little_Entente" title="Little Entente">
        Little Entente
       </a>
       , sensing an opportunity, invaded the country from three sides—Romania
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hungarian-Romanian_War" title="Hungarian-Romanian War">
        invaded
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Transylvania" title="Transylvania">
        Transylvania
       </a>
       , Czechoslovakia annexed
       <a href="/wiki/Upper_Hungary" title="Upper Hungary">
        Upper Hungary
       </a>
       (today's Slovakia), and a joint
       <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Serbia" title="Kingdom of Serbia">
        Serb
       </a>
       -
       <a href="/wiki/French_Army" title="French Army">
        French
       </a>
       coalition annexed
       <a href="/wiki/Vojvodina" title="Vojvodina">
        Vojvodina
       </a>
       and other southern regions. In March 1919, communists led by
       <a href="/wiki/B%C3%A9la_Kun" title="Béla Kun">
        Béla Kun
       </a>
       ousted the Károlyi government and proclaimed the
       <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_Soviet_Republic" title="Hungarian Soviet Republic">
        Hungarian Soviet Republic
       </a>
       (
       <i>
        Tanácsköztársaság
       </i>
       ), followed by a thorough
       <a href="/wiki/Red_Terror_(Hungary)" title="Red Terror (Hungary)">
        Red Terror
       </a>
       campaign. Despite some successes on the Czechoslovak front, Kun's forces were ultimately unable to resist the Romanian invasion; by August 1919, Romanian troops occupied Budapest and ousted Kun.
      </p>
      <p>
       In November 1919, rightist forces led by former Austro-Hungarian admiral
       <a href="/wiki/Mikl%C3%B3s_Horthy" title="Miklós Horthy">
        Miklós Horthy
       </a>
       entered Budapest; exhausted by the war and its aftermath, the populace accepted Horthy's leadership. In January 1920, parliamentary elections were held and Horthy was proclaimed Regent of the reestablished
       <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Hungary_(1920%E2%80%9346)" title="Kingdom of Hungary (1920–46)">
        Kingdom of Hungary
       </a>
       , inaugurating the so-called "Horthy era" (
       <i>
        Horthy-kor
       </i>
       ). The new government worked quickly to normalize foreign relations while turning a blind eye to a
       <a href="/wiki/White_Terror_(Hungary)" title="White Terror (Hungary)">
        White Terror
       </a>
       that swept through the countryside; extrajudicial killings of suspected communists and Jews lasted well into 1920. On June 4 of that year, the
       <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Trianon" title="Treaty of Trianon">
        Treaty of Trianon
       </a>
       established new borders for Hungary. The country lost 71% of its territory and 66% of its antebellum population, as well as many sources of raw materials and its sole
       <a href="/wiki/Port" title="Port">
        port
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Rijeka" title="Rijeka">
        Fiume
       </a>
       . Though the revision of the Treaty quickly rose to the top of the national political agenda, the Horthy government was not willing to resort to military intervention to do so.
      </p>
      <p>
       The Horthy regime's initial years were occupied by putsch attempts by
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Charles_IV_of_Hungary" title="Charles IV of Hungary">
        Charles IV
       </a>
       , the Austro-Hungarian
       <a href="/wiki/Pretender" title="Pretender">
        pretender
       </a>
       ; continued suppression of communists; and a migration crisis triggered by the Trianon territorial changes. Though free elections continued, Horthy's personality, and those of his personally selected prime ministers, dominated the political scene. The government's actions continued to drift right with the passage of antisemitic laws and, due to the continued isolation of the Little Entente, economic and then political gravitation toward
       <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Italy#Fascist_regime_(1922–1943)" title="Kingdom of Italy">
        Italy
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Nazi_Germany" title="Nazi Germany">
        Germany
       </a>
       . The
       <a href="/wiki/Great_Depression" title="Great Depression">
        Great Depression
       </a>
       further exacerbated the situation and the popularity of fascist politicians such as
       <a href="/wiki/Gyula_G%C3%B6mb%C3%B6s" title="Gyula Gömbös">
        Gyula Gömbös
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Ferenc_Sz%C3%A1lasi" title="Ferenc Szálasi">
        Ferenc Szálasi
       </a>
       , promising economic and social recovery, rose.
      </p>
      <p>
       Horthy's nationalist agenda reached its apogee in 1938 and 1940, when the Nazis rewarded Hungary's staunchly pro-Germany foreign policy in the
       <a href="/wiki/First_Vienna_Award" title="First Vienna Award">
        First
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Second_Vienna_Award" title="Second Vienna Award">
        Second Vienna Awards
       </a>
       , respectively, peacefully restoring ethnic-Hungarian-majority areas lost after Trianon. In 1939, Hungary regained further territory from Czechoslovakia
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Slovak-Hungarian_War" title="Slovak-Hungarian War">
        through force
       </a>
       . Hungary
       <a href="/wiki/Tripartite_Pact" title="Tripartite Pact">
        formally joined
       </a>
       the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Axis_Powers" title="Axis Powers">
        Axis Powers
       </a>
       on 20 November 1940, and in 1941, participated in the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/German_invasion_of_Yugoslavia" title="German invasion of Yugoslavia">
        invasion of Yugoslavia
       </a>
       , gaining some of its former territories in the south.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span id="World_War_II_1941.E2.80.931945">
       </span>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="World_War_II_1941–1945">
        World War II 1941–1945
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hungary&amp;action=edit&amp;section=11" title="Edit section: World War II 1941–1945">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hungary_during_World_War_II" title="Hungary during World War II">
        Hungary during World War II
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Holocaust_in_Hungary" title="Holocaust in Hungary">
        Holocaust in Hungary
       </a>
       , and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Soviet_occupation_of_Hungary" title="Soviet occupation of Hungary">
        Soviet occupation of Hungary
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Hungary_1941-44_Administrative_Map.png">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2157" data-file-width="4000" height="119" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/Hungary_1941-44_Administrative_Map.png/220px-Hungary_1941-44_Administrative_Map.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/Hungary_1941-44_Administrative_Map.png/330px-Hungary_1941-44_Administrative_Map.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/Hungary_1941-44_Administrative_Map.png/440px-Hungary_1941-44_Administrative_Map.png 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Hungary_1941-44_Administrative_Map.png" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Kingdom of Hungary, 1941–44
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Hungary formally entered World War II as an Axis Power on 26 June 1941, declaring war on the
       <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">
        Soviet Union
       </a>
       after unidentified planes bombed
       <a href="/wiki/Ko%C5%A1ice" title="Košice">
        Kassa
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Munkacheve" title="Munkacheve">
        Munkács
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Rakhiv" title="Rakhiv">
        Rahó
       </a>
       . Hungarian troops fought on the
       <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Front_(World_War_II)" title="Eastern Front (World War II)">
        Eastern Front
       </a>
       for two years. Despite
       <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Uman" title="Battle of Uman">
        some early successes
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-J._Lee_Ready_1995_page_130_95-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-J._Lee_Ready_1995_page_130-95">
         [95]
        </a>
       </sup>
       the Hungarian government began seeking a secret peace pact with
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Allies_(World_War_II)" title="Allies (World War II)">
        the Allies
       </a>
       after the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hungarian_Second_Army" title="Hungarian Second Army">
        Second Army
       </a>
       suffered catastrophic losses
       <a href="/wiki/Ostrogozhsk%E2%80%93Rossosh_Offensive" title="Ostrogozhsk–Rossosh Offensive">
        at the River Don
       </a>
       in January 1943. Learning of the planned defection, German troops
       <a href="/wiki/Operation_Margarethe" title="Operation Margarethe">
        occupied Hungary
       </a>
       on 19 March 1944 to guarantee Horthy's compliance. In October, as the Soviet front approached and the Hungarian government made further efforts to disengage from the war, German troops ousted Horthy and installed a puppet government under Szálasi's fascist
       <a href="/wiki/Arrow_Cross_Party" title="Arrow Cross Party">
        Arrow Cross Party
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-J._Lee_Ready_1995_page_130_95-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-J._Lee_Ready_1995_page_130-95">
         [95]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Szálasi pledged all the country's capabilities in service of the German war machine. By October 1944, the Soviets had reached the river Tisza, and despite
       <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Debrecen" title="Battle of Debrecen">
        some losses
       </a>
       , succeeded in encircling and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Battle_of_Budapest" title="Battle of Budapest">
        besieging Budapest
       </a>
       in December.
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bundesarchiv_Bild_101I-680-8285A-08,_Budapest,_Festnahme_von_Juden.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="512" data-file-width="796" height="142" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/Bundesarchiv_Bild_101I-680-8285A-08%2C_Budapest%2C_Festnahme_von_Juden.jpg/220px-Bundesarchiv_Bild_101I-680-8285A-08%2C_Budapest%2C_Festnahme_von_Juden.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/Bundesarchiv_Bild_101I-680-8285A-08%2C_Budapest%2C_Festnahme_von_Juden.jpg/330px-Bundesarchiv_Bild_101I-680-8285A-08%2C_Budapest%2C_Festnahme_von_Juden.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/Bundesarchiv_Bild_101I-680-8285A-08%2C_Budapest%2C_Festnahme_von_Juden.jpg/440px-Bundesarchiv_Bild_101I-680-8285A-08%2C_Budapest%2C_Festnahme_von_Juden.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bundesarchiv_Bild_101I-680-8285A-08,_Budapest,_Festnahme_von_Juden.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jewish" title="Jewish">
          Jewish
         </a>
         women being arrested on Wesselényi Street in
         <a href="/wiki/Budapest" title="Budapest">
          Budapest
         </a>
         during
         <a href="/wiki/The_Holocaust" title="The Holocaust">
          The Holocaust
         </a>
         , ca. 20–22 October 1944
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       After German occupation, Hungary
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Holocaust_in_Hungary" title="Holocaust in Hungary">
        participated
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/The_Holocaust" title="The Holocaust">
        the Holocaust
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bbc-no-warning-to-hungary-jews_96-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-bbc-no-warning-to-hungary-jews-96">
         [96]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-97">
        <a href="#cite_note-97">
         [97]
        </a>
       </sup>
       During the German occupation in May–June 1944, the Arrow Cross and Hungarian police deported nearly 440,000 Jews, mainly to
       <a href="/wiki/Auschwitz_concentration_camp" title="Auschwitz concentration camp">
        Auschwitz
       </a>
       . Nearly all of these were murdered.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-98">
        <a href="#cite_note-98">
         [98]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The Swedish Diplomat
       <a href="/wiki/Raoul_Wallenberg" title="Raoul Wallenberg">
        Raoul Wallenberg
       </a>
       managed to save a considerable number of Hungarian Jews by giving them Swedish passports.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-99">
        <a href="#cite_note-99">
         [99]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Rudolf_Kastner" title="Rudolf Kastner">
        Rudolf Kastner
       </a>
       (original spelling Kasztner), one of the leaders of the Hungarian
       <a href="/wiki/Aid_and_Rescue_Committee" title="Aid and Rescue Committee">
        Aid and Rescue Committee
       </a>
       , bribed senior SS officers such as
       <a href="/wiki/Adolf_Eichmann" title="Adolf Eichmann">
        Adolf Eichmann
       </a>
       to allow some Jews to escape.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-100">
        <a href="#cite_note-100">
         [100]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-101">
        <a href="#cite_note-101">
         [101]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-102">
        <a href="#cite_note-102">
         [102]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The Horthy government's complicity in the Holocaust remains a point of controversy and contention.
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Lanc_hid_-_Budapest_3_Febr_1946_Foto_Takkk_Hungary.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2748" data-file-width="3840" height="157" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Lanc_hid_-_Budapest_3_Febr_1946_Foto_Takkk_Hungary.jpg/220px-Lanc_hid_-_Budapest_3_Febr_1946_Foto_Takkk_Hungary.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Lanc_hid_-_Budapest_3_Febr_1946_Foto_Takkk_Hungary.jpg/330px-Lanc_hid_-_Budapest_3_Febr_1946_Foto_Takkk_Hungary.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Lanc_hid_-_Budapest_3_Febr_1946_Foto_Takkk_Hungary.jpg/440px-Lanc_hid_-_Budapest_3_Febr_1946_Foto_Takkk_Hungary.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Lanc_hid_-_Budapest_3_Febr_1946_Foto_Takkk_Hungary.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sz%C3%A9chenyi_Chain_Bridge" title="Széchenyi Chain Bridge">
          Széchenyi Chain Bridge
         </a>
         and the
         <a href="/wiki/Buda_Castle" title="Buda Castle">
          Buda Castle
         </a>
         in ruins after World War II (1946)
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The war left Hungary devastated, destroying over 60% of the economy and causing significant
       <a href="/wiki/World_War_II_casualties#endnote_Hungary" title="World War II casualties">
        loss of life
       </a>
       . In addition to the over 600,000 Hungarian Jews killed,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ind09/96_103-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-ind09/96-103">
         [103]
        </a>
       </sup>
       as many as 280,000
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EU38_104-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-EU38-104">
         [104]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-105">
        <a href="#cite_note-105">
         [105]
        </a>
       </sup>
       other Hungarians were raped, murdered and executed or deported for slave labor by Czechoslovaks,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-106">
        <a href="#cite_note-106">
         [106]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-107">
        <a href="#cite_note-107">
         [107]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-108">
        <a href="#cite_note-108">
         [108]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-109">
        <a href="#cite_note-109">
         [109]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-110">
        <a href="#cite_note-110">
         [110]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-111">
        <a href="#cite_note-111">
         [111]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Soviet
       <a href="/wiki/Red_Army" title="Red Army">
        Red Army
       </a>
       troops,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-112">
        <a href="#cite_note-112">
         [112]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-113">
        <a href="#cite_note-113">
         [113]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-114">
        <a href="#cite_note-114">
         [114]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and Yugoslavs.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-115">
        <a href="#cite_note-115">
         [115]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       On 13 February 1945, Budapest surrendered; by April, German troops left the country under Soviet military occupation. 200,000 Hungarians were expelled from Czechoslovakia in exchange for 70,000 Slovaks living in Hungary. 202,000 ethnic Germans were expelled to Germany,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-116">
        <a href="#cite_note-116">
         [116]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and through the 1947
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Paris_Peace_Treaties" title="Paris Peace Treaties">
        Paris Peace Treaties
       </a>
       , Hungary was again reduced to its immediate post-Trianon borders.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span id="Communism_1945.E2.80.931989">
       </span>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Communism_1945–1989">
        Communism 1945–1989
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hungary&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12" title="Edit section: Communism 1945–1989">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hungarian_Republic_(1946%E2%80%9349)" title="Hungarian Republic (1946–49)">
        Hungarian Republic (1946–49)
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_People%27s_Republic" title="Hungarian People's Republic">
        Hungarian People's Republic
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_Revolution_of_1956" title="Hungarian Revolution of 1956">
        Hungarian Revolution of 1956
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Sz%C3%A9tl%C5%91tt_harckocsi_a_M%C3%B3ricz_Zsigmond_k%C3%B6rt%C3%A9ren.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1552" data-file-width="2243" height="152" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Sz%C3%A9tl%C5%91tt_harckocsi_a_M%C3%B3ricz_Zsigmond_k%C3%B6rt%C3%A9ren.jpg/220px-Sz%C3%A9tl%C5%91tt_harckocsi_a_M%C3%B3ricz_Zsigmond_k%C3%B6rt%C3%A9ren.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Sz%C3%A9tl%C5%91tt_harckocsi_a_M%C3%B3ricz_Zsigmond_k%C3%B6rt%C3%A9ren.jpg/330px-Sz%C3%A9tl%C5%91tt_harckocsi_a_M%C3%B3ricz_Zsigmond_k%C3%B6rt%C3%A9ren.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Sz%C3%A9tl%C5%91tt_harckocsi_a_M%C3%B3ricz_Zsigmond_k%C3%B6rt%C3%A9ren.jpg/440px-Sz%C3%A9tl%C5%91tt_harckocsi_a_M%C3%B3ricz_Zsigmond_k%C3%B6rt%C3%A9ren.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Sz%C3%A9tl%C5%91tt_harckocsi_a_M%C3%B3ricz_Zsigmond_k%C3%B6rt%C3%A9ren.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         A destroyed Soviet tank in Budapest during the
         <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_Revolution_of_1956" title="Hungarian Revolution of 1956">
          1956 Revolution
         </a>
         ;
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Time_Magazine" title="Time Magazine">
          Time
         </a>
         's
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Time_Magazine_Person_of_the_Year" title="Time Magazine Person of the Year">
          Man of the Year
         </a>
         for 1956 was the Hungarian Freedom Fighter
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-117">
          <a href="#cite_note-117">
           [117]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Following the defeat of Nazi Germany, Hungary became a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Soviet_satellite" title="Soviet satellite">
        satellite state
       </a>
       of the Soviet Union. The Soviet leadership selected
       <a href="/wiki/M%C3%A1ty%C3%A1s_R%C3%A1kosi" title="Mátyás Rákosi">
        Mátyás Rákosi
       </a>
       to front the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Stalinization" title="Stalinization">
        Stalinization
       </a>
       of the country, and Rákosi
       <i>
        de facto
       </i>
       ruled Hungary from 1949 to 1956. His government's policies of militarization, industrialization, collectivization, and war compensation led to a severe decline in living standards. In imitation of Stalin's
       <a href="/wiki/KGB" title="KGB">
        KGB
       </a>
       , the Rákosi government established a secret political police, the
       <a href="/wiki/State_Protection_Authority" title="State Protection Authority">
        ÁVH
       </a>
       , to enforce the new regime. The purges that followed saw approximately 350,000 officials and intellectuals imprisoned or executed from 1948 to 1956.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-118">
        <a href="#cite_note-118">
         [118]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Many freethinkers, democrats, and Horthy-era dignitaries were secretly arrested and extrajudicially interned in domestic and foreign
       <a href="/wiki/Gulag" title="Gulag">
        Gulags
       </a>
       . Some 600,000 Hungarians were deported to Soviet labor camps, where at least 200,000 died.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-119">
        <a href="#cite_note-119">
         [119]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       After Stalin's death in 1953, the Soviet Union pursued a program of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Destalinization" title="Destalinization">
        destalinization
       </a>
       that was inimical to Rákosi, leading to his deposition. The following political cooling saw the ascent of
       <a href="/wiki/Imre_Nagy" title="Imre Nagy">
        Imre Nagy
       </a>
       to the premiership, and the growing interest of students and intellectuals in political life. Nagy promised market liberalization and political openness, while Rákosi opposed both vigorously. Rákosi eventually managed to discredit Nagy and replace him with the more hard-line
       <a href="/wiki/Ern%C5%91_Ger%C5%91" title="Ernő Gerő">
        Ernő Gerő
       </a>
       . Hungary joined the
       <a href="/wiki/Warsaw_Pact" title="Warsaw Pact">
        Warsaw Pact
       </a>
       in May 1955, as societal dissatisfaction with the regime swelled. Following the firing on peaceful demonstrations by Soviet soldiers and secret police, and rallies throughout the country on 23 October 1956, protesters took to the streets in Budapest, initiating the
       <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_Revolution_of_1956" title="Hungarian Revolution of 1956">
        1956 Revolution
       </a>
       . In an effort to quell the chaos, Nagy returned as premier, promised free elections, and took Hungary out of the Warsaw Pact.
      </p>
      <p>
       The violence nonetheless continued as revolutionary militias sprung up against the Soviet Army and the ÁVH; the roughly 3,000-strong resistance fought Soviet tanks using
       <a href="/wiki/Molotov_cocktail" title="Molotov cocktail">
        Molotov cocktails
       </a>
       and machine-pistols. Though the preponderance of the Soviets was immense, they suffered heavy losses, and by 30 October 1956 most Soviet troops had withdrawn from Budapest to garrison the countryside. For a time, the Soviet leadership was unsure how to respond to developments in Hungary, but eventually decided to intervene to prevent a destabilization of the Soviet bloc. On 4 November reinforcements of more than 150,000 troops and 2,500 tanks entered the country from the Soviet Union.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-120">
        <a href="#cite_note-120">
         [120]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Nearly 20,000 Hungarians were killed resisting the intervention, while an additional 21,600 were imprisoned afterwards for political reasons. Some 13,000 were interned and 230 brought to trial and executed. Nagy was captured to be executed in 1958. Because borders had briefly been open, nearly a quarter of a million people had fled the country by the time the revolution was suppressed.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-121">
        <a href="#cite_note-121">
         [121]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span id="K.C3.A1d.C3.A1r_era_1956.E2.80.931988">
       </span>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Kádár_era_1956–1988">
        Kádár era 1956–1988
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hungary&amp;action=edit&amp;section=13" title="Edit section: Kádár era 1956–1988">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/Goulash_Communism" title="Goulash Communism">
        Goulash Communism
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:J%C3%A1nos_K%C3%A1d%C3%A1r_1962.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1908" data-file-width="1380" height="235" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/J%C3%A1nos_K%C3%A1d%C3%A1r_1962.jpg/170px-J%C3%A1nos_K%C3%A1d%C3%A1r_1962.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/J%C3%A1nos_K%C3%A1d%C3%A1r_1962.jpg/255px-J%C3%A1nos_K%C3%A1d%C3%A1r_1962.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/J%C3%A1nos_K%C3%A1d%C3%A1r_1962.jpg/340px-J%C3%A1nos_K%C3%A1d%C3%A1r_1962.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:J%C3%A1nos_K%C3%A1d%C3%A1r_1962.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/J%C3%A1nos_K%C3%A1d%C3%A1r" title="János Kádár">
          János Kádár
         </a>
         , General Secretary of MSZMP, the
         <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_Socialist_Workers%27_Party" title="Hungarian Socialist Workers' Party">
          Hungarian Socialist Workers' Party
         </a>
         (1956–1988)
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       After a second, briefer period of Soviet military occupation,
       <a href="/wiki/J%C3%A1nos_K%C3%A1d%C3%A1r" title="János Kádár">
        János Kádár
       </a>
       , Nagy's former Minister of State, was chosen by the Soviet leadership to head the new government and chair the new ruling
       <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_Socialist_Workers%27_Party" title="Hungarian Socialist Workers' Party">
        Socialist Workers' Party
       </a>
       (MSzMP). Kádár quickly normalized the situation. In 1963, the government granted a general amnesty and released the majority of those imprisoned for their active participation in the uprising. Kádár proclaimed a new policy line, according to which the people were no longer compelled to profess loyalty to the party if they tacitly accepted the Socialist regime as a fact of life. In many speeches, he described this as, "Those who are not against us are with us." Kádár introduced new planning priorities in the economy, such as allowing farmers significant plots of private land within the collective farm system (
       <i>
        háztáji gazdálkodás
       </i>
       ). The living standard rose as consumer good and food production took precedence over military production, which was reduced to one tenth of pre-revolutionary levels.
      </p>
      <p>
       In 1968, the
       <a href="/wiki/New_Economic_Mechanism" title="New Economic Mechanism">
        New Economic Mechanism
       </a>
       (NEM) introduced free-market elements into socialist command economy. From the 1960s through the late 1980s, Hungary was often referred to as "
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_happiest_barrack" title="The happiest barrack">
        the happiest barrack
       </a>
       " within the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eastern_bloc" title="Eastern bloc">
        Eastern bloc
       </a>
       . During the latter part of the Cold War Hungary's
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/GDP_per_capita" title="GDP per capita">
        GDP per capita
       </a>
       was fourth only to
       <a href="/wiki/East_Germany" title="East Germany">
        East Germany
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Czechoslovak_Socialist_Republic" title="Czechoslovak Socialist Republic">
        Czechoslovakia
       </a>
       , and the Soviet Union itself.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-madison185_122-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-madison185-122">
         [122]
        </a>
       </sup>
       As a result of this relatively high standard of living, a more liberalized economy, a less censored press, and less restricted travel rights, Hungary was generally considered one of the more liberal countries in which to live in Central Europe during communism. In the 1980s, however, living standards steeply declined again due to
       <a href="/wiki/Early_1980s_recession" title="Early 1980s recession">
        a worldwide recession
       </a>
       to which communism was unable to respond.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-123">
        <a href="#cite_note-123">
         [123]
        </a>
       </sup>
       By the time Kádár died in 1989, the Soviet Union was in steep decline and a younger generation of reformists saw liberalization as the solution to economic and social issues.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span id="Third_Republic_1989.E2.80.93present">
       </span>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Third_Republic_1989–present">
        Third Republic 1989–present
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hungary&amp;action=edit&amp;section=14" title="Edit section: Third Republic 1989–present">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Foundation_of_the_Visegr%C3%A1d_Group.tiff">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="540" data-file-width="1020" height="116" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Foundation_of_the_Visegr%C3%A1d_Group.tiff/lossy-page1-220px-Foundation_of_the_Visegr%C3%A1d_Group.tiff.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Foundation_of_the_Visegr%C3%A1d_Group.tiff/lossy-page1-330px-Foundation_of_the_Visegr%C3%A1d_Group.tiff.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Foundation_of_the_Visegr%C3%A1d_Group.tiff/lossy-page1-440px-Foundation_of_the_Visegr%C3%A1d_Group.tiff.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Foundation_of_the_Visegr%C3%A1d_Group.tiff" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The
         <a href="/wiki/Visegr%C3%A1d_Group" title="Visegrád Group">
          Visegrád Group
         </a>
         signing ceremony in February 1991
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/Revolutions_of_1989" title="Revolutions of 1989">
        Revolutions of 1989
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/2006_protests_in_Hungary" title="2006 protests in Hungary">
        2006 protests in Hungary
       </a>
      </div>
      <table class="plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-Refimprove" role="presentation">
       <tr>
        <td class="mbox-image">
         <div style="width:52px">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="399" data-file-width="512" height="39" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/75px-Question_book-new.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/100px-Question_book-new.svg.png 2x" width="50"/>
          </a>
         </div>
        </td>
        <td class="mbox-text">
         <div class="mbox-text-span">
          This article
          <b>
           needs additional citations for
           <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability">
            verification
           </a>
          </b>
          .
          <span class="hide-when-compact">
           Please help
           <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Hungary&amp;action=edit">
            improve this article
           </a>
           by
           <a href="/wiki/Help:Introduction_to_referencing_with_Wiki_Markup/1" title="Help:Introduction to referencing with Wiki Markup/1">
            adding citations to reliable sources
           </a>
           . Unsourced material may be challenged and removed.
          </span>
          <small>
           <i>
            (December 2017)
           </i>
          </small>
          <small class="hide-when-compact">
           <i>
            (
            <a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">
             Learn how and when to remove this template message
            </a>
            )
           </i>
          </small>
         </div>
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <p>
       Hungary's
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fall_of_communism" title="Fall of communism">
        transition from communism
       </a>
       to democracy and capitalism (
       <i>
        rendszerváltás
       </i>
       , "regime change") was peaceful and prompted by economic stagnation, domestic political pressure, and changing relations with other
       <a href="/wiki/Warsaw_Pact" title="Warsaw Pact">
        Warsaw Pact
       </a>
       countries. Although the MSzMP began
       <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_Round_Table_Talks" title="Hungarian Round Table Talks">
        Round Table Talks
       </a>
       with various opposition groups in March 1989, the reburial of Imre Nagy as a revolutionary martyr that June is widely considered the symbolic end of communism in Hungary. Over 100,000 people attended the Budapest ceremony without any significant government interference, and many speakers openly called for Soviet troops to leave the country. Free elections were held
       <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_parliamentary_election,_1990" title="Hungarian parliamentary election, 1990">
        in May 1990
       </a>
       , which saw the
       <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_Democratic_Forum" title="Hungarian Democratic Forum">
        Hungarian Democratic Forum
       </a>
       , a major conservative opposition group, elected to the head of a coalition government.
       <a href="/wiki/J%C3%B3zsef_Antall" title="József Antall">
        József Antall
       </a>
       became the first democratically elected Prime Minister since World War II
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Unsupported_attributions" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Words to watch">
          <span title="The material near this tag may use weasel words or too-vague attribution. (December 2017)">
           by whom?
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       With the removal of state subsidies and rapid privatization in 1991, Hungary was affected by a severe economic recession. The Antall government's austerity measures proved unpopular, and the Communist Party's legal and political heir, the
       <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_Socialist_Party" title="Hungarian Socialist Party">
        Socialist Party
       </a>
       , won the subsequent
       <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_parliamentary_election,_1994" title="Hungarian parliamentary election, 1994">
        1994 elections
       </a>
       . This abrupt shift in the political landscape was repeated in
       <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_parliamentary_election,_1998" title="Hungarian parliamentary election, 1998">
        1998
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_parliamentary_election,_2002" title="Hungarian parliamentary election, 2002">
        2002
       </a>
       ; each electoral cycle, the governing party was ousted and the erstwhile opposition elected. Like most other post-communist European states, however, Hungary broadly pursued an
       <a href="/wiki/European_integration" title="European integration">
        integrationist
       </a>
       agenda,
       <a href="/wiki/Enlargement_of_NATO" title="Enlargement of NATO">
        joining
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">
        NATO
       </a>
       in 1999 and the European Union
       <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_European_Union_membership_referendum,_2003" title="Hungarian European Union membership referendum, 2003">
        in 2004
       </a>
       . As a NATO member, Hungary was involved in the
       <a href="/wiki/Yugoslav_Wars" title="Yugoslav Wars">
        Yugoslav Wars
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       In 2006,
       <a href="/wiki/2006_protests_in_Hungary" title="2006 protests in Hungary">
        major protests
       </a>
       erupted after it leaked that socialist PM
       <a href="/wiki/Ferenc_Gyurcs%C3%A1ny" title="Ferenc Gyurcsány">
        Ferenc Gyurcsány
       </a>
       's
       <a href="/wiki/%C5%90sz%C3%B6d_speech" title="Őszöd speech">
        had claimed in a private speech
       </a>
       that his party "lied" to win the
       <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_parliamentary_election,_2006" title="Hungarian parliamentary election, 2006">
        recent elections
       </a>
       . The popularity of left-wing parties plummeted in the ensuing political upheaval, and in 2010,
       <a href="/wiki/Viktor_Orb%C3%A1n" title="Viktor Orbán">
        Viktor Orbán
       </a>
       's
       <a href="/wiki/National_conservatism" title="National conservatism">
        national-conservative
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Fidesz" title="Fidesz">
        Fidesz
       </a>
       was
       <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_parliamentary_election,_2010" title="Hungarian parliamentary election, 2010">
        elected
       </a>
       to a parliamentary
       <a href="/wiki/Supermajority" title="Supermajority">
        supermajority
       </a>
       . The legislature consequently approved a
       <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Hungary" title="Constitution of Hungary">
        new constitution
       </a>
       , among other sweeping governmental and legal changes. Although these developments were met with and still engender controversy, Fidesz secured a second supermajority
       <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_parliamentary_election,_2014" title="Hungarian parliamentary election, 2014">
        in 2014
       </a>
       . In 2015 Fidesz lost its two-thirds majority in parliament after a by-election defeat.
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">
        Geography
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hungary&amp;action=edit&amp;section=15" title="Edit section: Geography">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Hungary" title="Geography of Hungary">
        Geography of Hungary
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_national_parks_of_Hungary" title="List of national parks of Hungary">
        List of national parks of Hungary
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Magyar_racka_juh.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="900" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Magyar_racka_juh.jpg/220px-Magyar_racka_juh.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Magyar_racka_juh.jpg/330px-Magyar_racka_juh.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Magyar_racka_juh.jpg/440px-Magyar_racka_juh.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Magyar_racka_juh.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         A flock of
         <a href="/wiki/Racka" title="Racka">
          Racka
         </a>
         sheep in the
         <a href="/wiki/Fert%C5%91-Hans%C3%A1g_National_Park" title="Fertő-Hanság National Park">
          Fertő-Hanság National Park
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Hungary's geography has traditionally been defined by its two main waterways, the
       <a href="/wiki/Danube" title="Danube">
        Danube
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Tisza" title="Tisza">
        Tisza
       </a>
       rivers. The common tripartite division of the country into three sections—
       <i>
        Dunántúl
       </i>
       ("beyond the Danube",
       <a href="/wiki/Transdanubia" title="Transdanubia">
        Transdanubia
       </a>
       ),
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Tisz%C3%A1nt%C3%BAl" title="Tiszántúl">
         Tiszántúl
        </a>
       </i>
       ("beyond the Tisza"), and
       <i>
        Duna-Tisza köze
       </i>
       ("between the Danube and Tisza")—is a reflection of this. The Danube flows north-south right through the center of contemporary Hungary, and the entire country lies within its
       <a href="/wiki/Drainage_basin" title="Drainage basin">
        drainage basin
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Transdanubia" title="Transdanubia">
        Transdanubia
       </a>
       , which stretches westward from the center of the country toward Austria, is a primarily hilly region with a terrain varied by low mountains. These include the very eastern stretch of the
       <a href="/wiki/Alps" title="Alps">
        Alps
       </a>
       ,
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Alpokalja" title="Alpokalja">
         Alpokalja
        </a>
       </i>
       , in the west of the country, the
       <a href="/wiki/Transdanubian_Mountains" title="Transdanubian Mountains">
        Transdanubian Mountains
       </a>
       in the central region of Transdanubia, and the
       <a href="/wiki/Mecsek" title="Mecsek">
        Mecsek
       </a>
       Mountains and
       <a href="/wiki/Vill%C3%A1ny_Mountains" title="Villány Mountains">
        Villány Mountains
       </a>
       in the south. The highest point of the area is the Írott-kő in the Alps, at 882 metres (2,894 ft). The
       <a href="/wiki/Little_Hungarian_Plain" title="Little Hungarian Plain">
        Little Hungarian Plain
       </a>
       (
       <i>
        Kisalföld
       </i>
       ) is found in northern Transdanubia.
       <a href="/wiki/Lake_Balaton" title="Lake Balaton">
        Lake Balaton
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Lake_H%C3%A9v%C3%ADz" title="Lake Hévíz">
        Lake Hévíz
       </a>
       , the largest lake in Central Europe and the largest thermal lake in the world, respectively, are in Transdanubia as well.
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <i>
        Duna-Tisza köze
       </i>
       and
       <i>
        Tiszántúl
       </i>
       are characterized mainly by the
       <a href="/wiki/Great_Hungarian_Plain" title="Great Hungarian Plain">
        Great Hungarian Plain
       </a>
       (
       <i>
        Alföld
       </i>
       ), which stretches across most of the eastern and southeastern areas of the country. To the north of the Plain are the foothills of the
       <a href="/wiki/Carpathian_Mountains" title="Carpathian Mountains">
        Carpathians
       </a>
       in a wide band near the
       <a href="/wiki/Slovakia" title="Slovakia">
        Slovakian
       </a>
       border. The
       <a href="/wiki/K%C3%A9kes" title="Kékes">
        Kékes
       </a>
       at 1,014 m or 3,327 ft is the tallest mountain in Hungary and is found here.
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Phytogeography" title="Phytogeography">
        Phytogeographically
       </a>
       , Hungary belongs to the Central European province of the
       <a href="/wiki/Circumboreal_Region" title="Circumboreal Region">
        Circumboreal Region
       </a>
       within the
       <a href="/wiki/Boreal_Kingdom" title="Boreal Kingdom">
        Boreal Kingdom
       </a>
       . According to the
       <a href="/wiki/World_Wide_Fund_for_Nature" title="World Wide Fund for Nature">
        WWF
       </a>
       , the territory of Hungary belongs to the ecoregion of Pannonian mixed forests.
      </p>
      <p>
       Hungary has 10 national parks, 145 minor nature reserves, and 35 landscape protection areas.
      </p>
      <ul class="gallery mw-gallery-packed">
       <li class="gallerybox" style="width: 190px">
        <div style="width: 190px">

           </a>
          </p>

          </p>

        </div>

           The
           <a href="/wiki/Tisza" title="Tisza">

           </a>

           <a href="/wiki/Central_Europe" title="Central Europe">
            Central Europe
           </a>
           .
          </p>
         </div>
        </div>

           is one of them.
          </p>
         </div>
        </div>

          </p>
         </div>

      </ul>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">
        Climate
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hungary&amp;action=edit&amp;section=16" title="Edit section: Climate">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       Hungary has a
       <a href="/wiki/Continental_climate" title="Continental climate">
        continental climate
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-124">
        <a href="#cite_note-124">
         [124]
        </a>
       </sup>
       with hot summers with low overall humidity levels but frequent rainshowers and cold snowy winters. Average annual temperature is 9.7 °C (49.5 °F). Temperature extremes are 41.9 °C (107.4 °F) on 20 July 2007 at Kiskunhalas in the summer and −35 °C (−31.0 °F) on 16 February 1940 Miskolc-Görömbölytapolca in the winter. Average high temperature in the summer is 23 to 28 °C (73 to 82 °F) and average low temperature in the winter is −3 to −7 °C (27 to 19 °F). The average yearly rainfall is approximately 600 mm (23.6 in). A small, southern region of the country near
       <a href="/wiki/P%C3%A9cs" title="Pécs">
        Pécs
       </a>
       enjoys a reputation for a
       <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_climate" title="Mediterranean climate">
        Mediterranean climate
       </a>
       , but in reality it is only slightly warmer than the rest of the country and still receives snow during the winter.
      </p>
      <p>
       Hungary is ranked sixth in an environmental protection index by
       <i>
        GW
       </i>
       /
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Climate_Action_Network" title="Climate Action Network">
         CAN
        </a>
       </i>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-125">
        <a href="#cite_note-125">
         [125]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Government_and_politics">
        Government and politics
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hungary&amp;action=edit&amp;section=17" title="Edit section: Government and politics">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>

        Taxation in Hungary
       </a>
      </div>
