      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_relations">
        Foreign relations
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hungary&amp;action=edit&amp;section=21" title="Edit section: Foreign relations">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Hungary" title="Foreign relations of Hungary">
        Foreign relations of Hungary
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Necasmeeting.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="945" data-file-width="1417" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Necasmeeting.jpg/220px-Necasmeeting.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Necasmeeting.jpg/330px-Necasmeeting.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Necasmeeting.jpg/440px-Necasmeeting.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Necasmeeting.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Meeting of
         <a href="/wiki/Visegr%C3%A1d_Group" title="Visegrád Group">
          Visegrád Group
         </a>
         leaders, plus Germany and France in 2013
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:BIMUN_2012_opening_1.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="682" data-file-width="1024" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/BIMUN_2012_opening_1.jpg/220px-BIMUN_2012_opening_1.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/BIMUN_2012_opening_1.jpg/330px-BIMUN_2012_opening_1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/BIMUN_2012_opening_1.jpg/440px-BIMUN_2012_opening_1.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:BIMUN_2012_opening_1.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">
          United Nations
         </a>
         conference in the assembly hall of
         <a href="/wiki/House_of_Magnates" title="House of Magnates">
          House of Magnates
         </a>
         in the
         <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_Parliament_Building" title="Hungarian Parliament Building">
          Hungarian Parliament
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Hungary wields considerable influence in
       <a href="/wiki/Central_and_Eastern_Europe" title="Central and Eastern Europe">
        Central and Eastern Europe
       </a>
       and is a
       <a href="/wiki/Middle_power" title="Middle power">
        middle power
       </a>
       in international affairs.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Solomon_29-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Solomon-29">
         [29]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Higott-Cooper_30-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Higott-Cooper-30">
         [30]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Foreign_policy" title="Foreign policy">
        foreign policy
       </a>
       of Hungary is based on four basic commitments: to
       <a href="/wiki/Atlanticism" title="Atlanticism">
        Atlantic co-operation
       </a>
       , to
       <a href="/wiki/European_integration" title="European integration">
        European integration
       </a>
       , to
       <a href="/wiki/International_development" title="International development">
        international development
       </a>
       and to
       <a href="/wiki/International_law" title="International law">
        international law
       </a>
       . The
       <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Hungary" title="Economy of Hungary">
        Hungarian economy
       </a>
       is fairly open and relies strongly on
       <a href="/wiki/International_trade" title="International trade">
        international trade
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       Hungary has been a member of the
       <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">
        United Nations
       </a>
       since December 1955 and a member of the
       <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">
        European Union
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">
        NATO
       </a>
       , the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development" title="Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development">
        OECD
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Visegr%C3%A1d_Group" title="Visegrád Group">
        Visegrád Group
       </a>
       , the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/WTO" title="WTO">
        WTO
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">
        World Bank
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Asian_Infrastructure_Investment_Bank" title="Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank">
        AIIB
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund" title="International Monetary Fund">
        IMF
       </a>
       . Hungary took on the presidency of the
       <a href="/wiki/Council_of_the_European_Union" title="Council of the European Union">
        Council of the European Union
       </a>
       for half a year in 2011 and the next will be in 2024. In 2015, Hungary was the fifth largest
       <a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD">
        OECD
       </a>
       Non-DAC donor of
       <a href="/wiki/Development_aid" title="Development aid">
        development aid
       </a>
       in the world, which represents
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_development_aid_country_donors" title="List of development aid country donors">
        0.13% of its Gross National Income
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       Hungary's capital city, Budapest, is home to more than 100 embassies and representative bodies as an international political actor.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-140">
        <a href="#cite_note-140">
         [140]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Hungary hosts the main and regional headquarters of many international organizations as well, including
       <a href="/wiki/European_Institute_of_Innovation_and_Technology" title="European Institute of Innovation and Technology">
        European Institute of Innovation and Technology
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/European_Police_College" title="European Police College">
        European Police College
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_High_Commissioner_for_Refugees" title="United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees">
        United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Food_and_Agriculture_Organization_of_the_United_Nations" title="Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations">
        Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/International_Centre_for_Democratic_Transition" title="International Centre for Democratic Transition">
        International Centre for Democratic Transition
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Institute_of_International_Education" title="Institute of International Education">
        Institute of International Education
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/International_Labour_Organization" title="International Labour Organization">
        International Labour Organization
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/International_Organization_for_Migration" title="International Organization for Migration">
        International Organization for Migration
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/International_Federation_of_Red_Cross_and_Red_Crescent_Societies" title="International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies">
        International Red Cross
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Regional_Environmental_Center_for_Central_and_Eastern_Europe" title="Regional Environmental Center for Central and Eastern Europe">
        Regional Environmental Center for Central and Eastern Europe
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Danube_Commission_(1948)" title="Danube Commission (1948)">
        Danube Commission
       </a>
       and others.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-141">
        <a href="#cite_note-141">
         [141]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Since 1989, Hungary's top foreign policy goal has been achieving integration into Western economic and security organizations. Hungary joined the
       <a href="/wiki/Partnership_for_Peace" title="Partnership for Peace">
        Partnership for Peace
       </a>
       program in 1994 and has actively supported the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/IFOR" title="IFOR">
        IFOR
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/SFOR" title="SFOR">
        SFOR
       </a>
       missions in Bosnia. Hungary since 1989 has also improved its often frosty neighborly relations by signing basic treaties with
       <a href="/wiki/Romania" title="Romania">
        Romania
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Slovakia" title="Slovakia">
        Slovakia
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Ukraine" title="Ukraine">
        Ukraine
       </a>
       . These renounce all outstanding territorial claims and lay the foundation for constructive relations. However, the issue of
       <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_diaspora" title="Hungarian diaspora">
        ethnic Hungarian minority
       </a>
       rights in Romania, Slovakia and Serbia periodically causes bilateral tensions to flare up. Hungary since 1989 has signed all of the
       <a href="/wiki/Organization_for_Security_and_Co-operation_in_Europe" title="Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe">
        OSCE
       </a>
       documents, and served as the OSCE's Chairman-in-Office in 1997.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Military">
        Military
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hungary&amp;action=edit&amp;section=22" title="Edit section: Military">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hungarian_Defence_Force" title="Hungarian Defence Force">
        Hungarian Defence Force
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       The 2016
       <a href="/wiki/Global_Peace_Index" title="Global Peace Index">
        Global Peace Index
       </a>
       ranked Hungary 19th out of 163 countries. The
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_heads_of_state_of_Hungary" title="List of heads of state of Hungary">
        President
       </a>
       holds the title of
       <a href="/wiki/Commander-in-chief" title="Commander-in-chief">
        commander-in-chief
       </a>
       of the nation's armed forces. The
       <a href="/wiki/Minister_of_Defence_(Hungary)" title="Minister of Defence (Hungary)">
        Ministry of Defence
       </a>
       jointly with
       <a href="/wiki/General_Staff_of_the_Armed_Forces_of_the_Republic_of_Hungary" title="General Staff of the Armed Forces of the Republic of Hungary">
        Chief of staff
       </a>
       administers the armed forces, including the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hungarian_Ground_Force" title="Hungarian Ground Force">
        Hungarian Ground Force
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_Air_Force" title="Hungarian Air Force">
        Hungarian Air Force
       </a>
       . Since 2007, the Hungarian Armed Forces is under a unified command structure. The Ministry of Defence maintains the political and civil control over the army. A subordinate Joint Forces Command is coordinating and commanding the HDF corps. In 2016, the armed forces had 31,080 personnel on active duty, the operative reserve brought the total number of troops to fifty thousand. In 2017, military spending will be $1.21 billion, about 0.94% of the country's GDP, well below the NATO target of 2%. In 2012, the government adopted a resolution in which it pledged to increase defence spending to 1.4% of GDP by 2022.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-142">
        <a href="#cite_note-142">
         [142]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <table class="toccolours" style="float:right; margin:0 0 1em 1em; border:1px #ddd solid;">
       <caption>
        <b>
         Branches of the Hungarian Defence Forces
        </b>
       </caption>
       <tr style="text-align:center;">
        <td style="width:120px;">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Hunspec.jpg">
          <img alt="Hunspec.jpg" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="961" data-file-width="1500" height="160" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Hunspec.jpg/250px-Hunspec.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Hunspec.jpg/375px-Hunspec.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Hunspec.jpg/500px-Hunspec.jpg 2x" width="250"/>
         </a>
         <br/>
         <small>
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hungarian_Ground_Force" title="Hungarian Ground Force">
           Hungarian Ground Force
          </a>
          <br/>
          <a href="/wiki/HDF_34th_Bercs%C3%A9nyi_L%C3%A1szl%C3%B3_Special_Forces_Battalion" title="HDF 34th Bercsényi László Special Forces Battalion">
           HDF 34th Special Forces Battalion
          </a>
         </small>
        </td>
        <td style="width:120px;">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:JAS_39_pair_HuAF_Kecskem%C3%A9t_2007.JPG">
          <img alt="JAS 39 pair HuAF Kecskemét 2007.JPG" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="1031" data-file-width="1548" height="160" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/JAS_39_pair_HuAF_Kecskem%C3%A9t_2007.JPG/240px-JAS_39_pair_HuAF_Kecskem%C3%A9t_2007.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/JAS_39_pair_HuAF_Kecskem%C3%A9t_2007.JPG/361px-JAS_39_pair_HuAF_Kecskem%C3%A9t_2007.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/JAS_39_pair_HuAF_Kecskem%C3%A9t_2007.JPG/481px-JAS_39_pair_HuAF_Kecskem%C3%A9t_2007.JPG 2x" width="240"/>
         </a>
         <br/>
         <small>
          <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_Air_Force" title="Hungarian Air Force">
           Hungarian Air Force
          </a>
          <br/>
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/JAS_39_Gripen" title="JAS 39 Gripen">
           JAS 39 Gripen
          </a>
          <a href="/wiki/Multirole_combat_aircraft" title="Multirole combat aircraft">
           multirole combat aircraft
          </a>
         </small>
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Military_service" title="Military service">
        Military service
       </a>
       is voluntary, though
       <a href="/wiki/Conscription" title="Conscription">
        conscription
       </a>
       may occur in wartime. In a significant move for modernization, Hungary decided in 2001 to buy 14
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/JAS_39_Gripen" title="JAS 39 Gripen">
        JAS 39 Gripen
       </a>
       fighter aircraft for about 800 million EUR. Hungarian National Cyber Security Center is re-organized in 2016 in order to become more efficient through
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cyber_security" title="Cyber security">
        cyber security
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-143">
        <a href="#cite_note-143">
         [143]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In 2016, the Hungarian military has about 700 troops stationed in foreign countries as part of international peacekeeping forces, including 100 HDF troops in the
       <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">
        NATO
       </a>
       -led
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISAF" title="ISAF">
        ISAF
       </a>
       force in
       <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan" title="Afghanistan">
        Afghanistan
       </a>
       , 210 Hungarian soldiers in
       <a href="/wiki/Kosovo" title="Kosovo">
        Kosovo
       </a>
       under command of
       <a href="/wiki/Kosovo_Force" title="Kosovo Force">
        KFOR
       </a>
       , and 160 troops in
       <a href="/wiki/Bosnia_and_Herzegovina" title="Bosnia and Herzegovina">
        Bosnia and Herzegovina
       </a>
       . Hungary sent 300 strong logistics unit to Iraq in order to help the US occupation with armed transport convoys, though public opinion opposed the country's participation in the war. One soldier was
       <a href="/wiki/Killed_in_action" title="Killed in action">
        killed in action
       </a>
       because of a roadside bomb in Iraq.
      </p>
      <p>
       During the 18th and 19th century,
       <a href="/wiki/Hussar" title="Hussar">
        Hungarian Hussars
       </a>
       rose to international fame and served as a model for light cavalry in many European countries.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-144">
        <a href="#cite_note-144">
         [144]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 1848–49 HDF achieved successes against better-trained and equipped Austrian forces, despite the Austrian advantage in numbers. In 1872, the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ludovica_Military_Academy" title="Ludovica Military Academy">
        Ludovica Military Academy
       </a>
       officially began training cadets. By 1873 HDF already had over 2,800 officers and 158,000 men organized into eighty-six battalions and fifty-eight squadrons. During WWI, out of the eight million men mobilized by
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Austro_Hungarian_Empire" title="Austro Hungarian Empire">
        Austro Hungarian Empire
       </a>
       , over one million died. During the 1930s and early 1940s, Hungary was preoccupied with regaining the territories and population lost in the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Trianon_peace_treaty" title="Trianon peace treaty">
        Trianon peace treaty
       </a>
       at Versailles in 1920. Conscription was introduced on a national basis in 1939. The peacetime strength of the
       <a href="/wiki/Royal_Hungarian_Army" title="Royal Hungarian Army">
        Royal Hungarian Army
       </a>
       grew to 80,000 men organized into seven corps commands.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-145">
        <a href="#cite_note-145">
         [145]
        </a>
       </sup>
       During WWII the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hungarian_Second_Army" title="Hungarian Second Army">
        Hungarian Second Army
       </a>
       was near to total devastation on banks of the
       <a href="/wiki/Don_River_(Russia)" title="Don River (Russia)">
        Don River
       </a>
       in December 1942 in
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Battle_for_Stalingrad" title="Battle for Stalingrad">
        Battle for Stalingrad
       </a>
       . During the Socialist and the
       <a href="/wiki/Warsaw_Pact" title="Warsaw Pact">
        Warsaw Pact
       </a>
       era (1947–1989), the entire 200,000 strong
       <a href="/wiki/Southern_Group_of_Forces" title="Southern Group of Forces">
        Southern Group of Forces
       </a>
       was garrisoned in Hungary, complete with artillery, tank regiments, air force and missile troops with nuclear weapons.
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">
        Economy
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hungary&amp;action=edit&amp;section=23" title="Edit section: Economy">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Hungary" title="Economy of Hungary">
        Economy of Hungary
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:EU_Single_Market.svg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1300" data-file-width="1300" height="220" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/EU_Single_Market.svg/220px-EU_Single_Market.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/EU_Single_Market.svg/330px-EU_Single_Market.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/EU_Single_Market.svg/440px-EU_Single_Market.svg.png 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:EU_Single_Market.svg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Hungary is part of the
         <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">
          European Union
         </a>
         's
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Internal_market" title="Internal market">
          internal market
         </a>
         with 508 million consumers and part of
         <a href="/wiki/Schengen_Area" title="Schengen Area">
          Schengen Area
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Hungary_Export_Treemap.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2085" data-file-width="2668" height="172" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Hungary_Export_Treemap.jpg/220px-Hungary_Export_Treemap.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Hungary_Export_Treemap.jpg/330px-Hungary_Export_Treemap.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Hungary_Export_Treemap.jpg/440px-Hungary_Export_Treemap.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Hungary_Export_Treemap.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Hungary's Export Treemap from
         <a class="external text" href="http://atlas.cid.harvard.edu/explore/tree_map/export/hun/all/show/2014/" rel="nofollow">
          Harvard Economic Complexity Observatory
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Hungary is an
       <a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD">
        OECD
       </a>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/High-income_economy" title="High-income economy">
        high-income
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Mixed_economy" title="Mixed economy">
        mixed economy
       </a>
       with
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_Human_Development_Index" title="List of countries by Human Development Index">
        very high human development index
       </a>
       and skilled
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Labour_force" title="Labour force">
        labour force
       </a>
       with the
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_income_equality" title="List of countries by income equality">
        16th lowest income inequality
       </a>
       in the world, furthermore it is the
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_economic_complexity" title="List of countries by economic complexity">
        15th most complex economy
       </a>
       according to the Economic Complexity Index.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-146">
        <a href="#cite_note-146">
         [146]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The Hungarian is the
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP)">
        57th-largest economy in the world
       </a>
       (out of 188 countries measured by
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/IMF" title="IMF">
        IMF
       </a>
       ) with $265.037 billion output,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-imf2_9-4">
        <a href="#cite_note-imf2-9">
         [9]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and ranks
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)_per_capita" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP) per capita">
        49th in the world in terms of GDP per capita
       </a>
       measured by
       <a href="/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity" title="Purchasing power parity">
        purchasing power parity
       </a>
       . Hungary is an export-oriented
       <a href="/wiki/Market_economy" title="Market economy">
        market economy
       </a>
       with a heavy emphasis on
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Foreign_trade" title="Foreign trade">
        foreign trade
       </a>
       , thus the country is the
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_exports" title="List of countries by exports">
        36th largest export economy
       </a>
       in the world. The country has more than $100 billion export in 2015 with high, $9.003 billion
       <a href="/wiki/Balance_of_trade" title="Balance of trade">
        trade surplus
       </a>
       , of which 79% went to the EU and 21% was extra-EU trade.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-147">
        <a href="#cite_note-147">
         [147]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Hungary has a more than 80%
       <a href="/wiki/Private_sector" title="Private sector">
        privately owned
       </a>
       economy with
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_tax_revenue_as_percentage_of_GDP" title="List of countries by tax revenue as percentage of GDP">
        39,1% overall taxation
       </a>
       , which provides the basis for the country's
       <a href="/wiki/Welfare_state" title="Welfare state">
        welfare economy
       </a>
       . On the expenditure side,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Household_consumption" title="Household consumption">
        household consumption
       </a>
       is the main component of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/GDP" title="GDP">
        GDP
       </a>
       and accounts for 50 percent of its total use, followed by gross fixed
       <a href="/wiki/Capital_formation" title="Capital formation">
        capital formation
       </a>
       with 22 percent and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Government_expenditure" title="Government expenditure">
        government expenditure
       </a>
       with 20 percent.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-148">
        <a href="#cite_note-148">
         [148]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Hungary continues to be one of the leading nations for attracting
       <a href="/wiki/Foreign_direct_investment" title="Foreign direct investment">
        foreign direct investment
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Central_and_Eastern_Europe" title="Central and Eastern Europe">
        Central and Eastern Europe
       </a>
       , the inward FDI in the country was $119.8 billion in 2015, while Hungary invests more than $50 billion abroad.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-149">
        <a href="#cite_note-149">
         [149]
        </a>
       </sup>
       As of 2015
       <sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
        <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Hungary&amp;action=edit">
         [update]
        </a>
       </sup>
       , the key trading partners of Hungary were Germany, Austria, Romania, Slovakia, France, Italy, Poland and Czech Republic.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-150">
        <a href="#cite_note-150">
         [150]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Major industries include food processing, pharmaceuticals, motor vehicles, information technology, chemicals, metallurgy, machinery, electrical goods, and tourism (in 2014 Hungary welcomed 12.1 million international tourists).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-151">
        <a href="#cite_note-151">
         [151]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Hungary is the largest electronics producer in
       <a href="/wiki/Central_and_Eastern_Europe" title="Central and Eastern Europe">
        Central and Eastern Europe
       </a>
       .
       <a href="/wiki/Electronics" title="Electronics">
        Electronics
       </a>
       manufacturing and research are among the main drivers of
       <a href="/wiki/Innovation" title="Innovation">
        innovation
       </a>
       and economic growth in the country. In the past 20 years Hungary has also grown into a major center for
       <a href="/wiki/Mobile_technology" title="Mobile technology">
        mobile technology
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Information_security" title="Information security">
        information security
       </a>
       , and related hardware research.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-152">
        <a href="#cite_note-152">
         [152]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Employment_rate" title="Employment rate">
        employment rate
       </a>
       in the economy was 68.3% in 2017,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-153">
        <a href="#cite_note-153">
         [153]
        </a>
       </sup>
       the employment structure shows the characteristics of
       <a href="/wiki/Post-industrial_society" title="Post-industrial society">
        post-industrial economies
       </a>
       , 63.2% of employed workforce work in service sector, the industry contributed by 29.7%, while agriculture with 7.1%. Unemployment rate was 4.1% in 2017 September,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-154">
        <a href="#cite_note-154">
         [154]
        </a>
       </sup>
       down from 11% during the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Financial_crisis_of_2007%E2%80%9308" title="Financial crisis of 2007–08">
        financial crisis of 2007–08
       </a>
       . Hungary is part of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Internal_market" title="Internal market">
        European single market
       </a>
       which represents more than 508 million consumers. Several domestic commercial policies are determined by agreements among European Union members and by EU legislation.
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Sz%C3%A9chenyi_Chain_Bridge_in_Budapest_at_night.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2000" data-file-width="3580" height="123" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/Sz%C3%A9chenyi_Chain_Bridge_in_Budapest_at_night.jpg/220px-Sz%C3%A9chenyi_Chain_Bridge_in_Budapest_at_night.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/Sz%C3%A9chenyi_Chain_Bridge_in_Budapest_at_night.jpg/330px-Sz%C3%A9chenyi_Chain_Bridge_in_Budapest_at_night.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/Sz%C3%A9chenyi_Chain_Bridge_in_Budapest_at_night.jpg/440px-Sz%C3%A9chenyi_Chain_Bridge_in_Budapest_at_night.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Sz%C3%A9chenyi_Chain_Bridge_in_Budapest_at_night.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Budapest" title="Budapest">
          Budapest
         </a>
         is a leading
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/R%26D" title="R&amp;D">
          R&amp;D
         </a>
         and
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Financial_center" title="Financial center">
          financial center
         </a>
         in
         <a href="/wiki/Central_and_Eastern_Europe" title="Central and Eastern Europe">
          Central and Eastern Europe
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Large
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_companies_of_Hungary" title="List of companies of Hungary">
        Hungarian companies
       </a>
       are included in the
       <a href="/wiki/BUX" title="BUX">
        BUX
       </a>
       , the Hungarian stock market index listed on
       <a href="/wiki/Budapest_Stock_Exchange" title="Budapest Stock Exchange">
        Budapest Stock Exchange
       </a>
       . Well-known companies include the
       <a href="/wiki/Fortune_Global_500" title="Fortune Global 500">
        Fortune Global 500
       </a>
       firm
       <a href="/wiki/MOL_Group" title="MOL Group">
        MOL Group
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/OTP_Bank" title="OTP Bank">
        OTP Bank
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gedeon_Richter_Plc." title="Gedeon Richter Plc.">
        Gedeon Richter Plc.
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Magyar_Telekom" title="Magyar Telekom">
        Magyar Telekom
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/CIG_Pannonia" title="CIG Pannonia">
        CIG Pannonia
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/FHB_Mortgage_Bank" title="FHB Mortgage Bank">
        FHB Bank
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Zwack_liqueur" title="Zwack liqueur">
        Zwack Unicum
       </a>
       and more.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-155">
        <a href="#cite_note-155">
         [155]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Besides this Hungary has a large portion of specialised
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Small_and_medium_enterprise" title="Small and medium enterprise">
        small and medium enterprise
       </a>
       , for example a significant number of automotive suppliers and technology
       <a href="/wiki/Startup_company" title="Startup company">
        start ups
       </a>
       among others.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-156">
        <a href="#cite_note-156">
         [156]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Budapest" title="Budapest">
        Budapest
       </a>
       is the financial and business capital of Hungary. The capital is a significant economic hub, classified as an Alpha-
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/World_city" title="World city">
        world city
       </a>
       in the study by the
       <a href="/wiki/Globalization_and_World_Cities_Research_Network" title="Globalization and World Cities Research Network">
        Globalization and World Cities Research Network
       </a>
       and it is the second fastest-developing
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Urban_economy" title="Urban economy">
        urban economy
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">
        Europe
       </a>
       as GDP per capita in the city increased by 2.4 per cent and employment by 4.7 per cent compared to the previous year in 2014.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-157">
        <a href="#cite_note-157">
         [157]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-158">
        <a href="#cite_note-158">
         [158]
        </a>
       </sup>
       On the national level, Budapest is the
       <a href="/wiki/Primate_city" title="Primate city">
        primate city
       </a>
       of Hungary regarding business and economy, accounting for 39% of the national income, the city has a
       <a href="/wiki/Gross_metropolitan_product" title="Gross metropolitan product">
        gross metropolitan product
       </a>
       more than $100 billion in 2015, making it one of the largest regional economies in the
       <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">
        European Union
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-159">
        <a href="#cite_note-159">
         [159]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-160">
        <a href="#cite_note-160">
         [160]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Budapest is also among the Top 100 GDP performing cities in the world, measured by
       <a href="/wiki/PricewaterhouseCoopers" title="PricewaterhouseCoopers">
        PricewaterhouseCoopers
       </a>
       and in a global city competitiveness ranking by
       <a href="/wiki/Economist_Intelligence_Unit" title="Economist Intelligence Unit">
        EIU
       </a>
       , Budapest stands before
       <a href="/wiki/Tel_Aviv" title="Tel Aviv">
        Tel Aviv
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Lisbon" title="Lisbon">
        Lisbon
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Moscow" title="Moscow">
        Moscow
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Johannesburg" title="Johannesburg">
        Johannesburg
       </a>
       among others.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-161">
        <a href="#cite_note-161">
         [161]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-162">
        <a href="#cite_note-162">
         [162]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Hungary maintains its own currency, the
       <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_forint" title="Hungarian forint">
        Hungarian forint
       </a>
       (HUF), although the economy fulfills the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Maastricht_criteria" title="Maastricht criteria">
        Maastricht criteria
       </a>
       with the exception of public debt,
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_public_debt" title="List of countries by public debt">
        but it is also significantly below the EU average
       </a>
       with the level of 75.3% in 2015. The
       <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_National_Bank" title="Hungarian National Bank">
        Hungarian National Bank
       </a>
       —founded in 1924, after the dissolution of
       <a href="/wiki/Austria-Hungary" title="Austria-Hungary">
        Austro-Hungarian Empire
       </a>
       —is currently focusing on price stability with an inflation target of 3%.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-163">
        <a href="#cite_note-163">
         [163]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Science_and_technology">
        Science and technology
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hungary&amp;action=edit&amp;section=24" title="Edit section: Science and technology">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Szentgyorgyi_Albert_es_a_c_vitamin_keplete_1937_okt_31_Pesti_Naplo.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="817" data-file-width="1118" height="161" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Szentgyorgyi_Albert_es_a_c_vitamin_keplete_1937_okt_31_Pesti_Naplo.jpg/220px-Szentgyorgyi_Albert_es_a_c_vitamin_keplete_1937_okt_31_Pesti_Naplo.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Szentgyorgyi_Albert_es_a_c_vitamin_keplete_1937_okt_31_Pesti_Naplo.jpg/330px-Szentgyorgyi_Albert_es_a_c_vitamin_keplete_1937_okt_31_Pesti_Naplo.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Szentgyorgyi_Albert_es_a_c_vitamin_keplete_1937_okt_31_Pesti_Naplo.jpg/440px-Szentgyorgyi_Albert_es_a_c_vitamin_keplete_1937_okt_31_Pesti_Naplo.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Szentgyorgyi_Albert_es_a_c_vitamin_keplete_1937_okt_31_Pesti_Naplo.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Albert_Szent-Gy%C3%B6rgyi" title="Albert Szent-Györgyi">
          Albert Szent-Györgyi
         </a>
         a
         <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize" title="Nobel Prize">
          Nobel Laureate in Medicine
         </a>
         for discovery of
         <a href="/wiki/Vitamin_C" title="Vitamin C">
          Vitamin C
         </a>
         . Nobel Prize has been awarded to
         <a href="/wiki/List_of_Hungarian_Nobel_laureates" title="List of Hungarian Nobel laureates">
          13 Hungarian laureates
         </a>
         .
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Laszlo_Lovasz_mg_1858.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2912" data-file-width="4368" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Laszlo_Lovasz_mg_1858.jpg/220px-Laszlo_Lovasz_mg_1858.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Laszlo_Lovasz_mg_1858.jpg/330px-Laszlo_Lovasz_mg_1858.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Laszlo_Lovasz_mg_1858.jpg/440px-Laszlo_Lovasz_mg_1858.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Laszlo_Lovasz_mg_1858.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/L%C3%A1szl%C3%B3_Lov%C3%A1sz" title="László Lovász">
          László Lovász
         </a>
         , he was awarded the
         <a href="/wiki/Wolf_Prize_in_Mathematics" title="Wolf Prize in Mathematics">
          Wolf Prize
         </a>
         and the
         <a href="/wiki/Knuth_Prize" title="Knuth Prize">
          Knuth Prize
         </a>
         in 1999, the
         <a href="/wiki/Kyoto_Prize" title="Kyoto Prize">
          Kyoto Prize
         </a>
         in 2010, he is the current president of the
         <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_Academy_of_Sciences" title="Hungarian Academy of Sciences">
          Hungarian Academy of Sciences
         </a>
         . He previously served as the president of
         <a href="/wiki/International_Mathematical_Union" title="International Mathematical Union">
          International Mathematical Union
         </a>
         .
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/Science_and_technology_in_Hungary" title="Science and technology in Hungary">
        Science and technology in Hungary
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Hungary" title="Education in Hungary">
        Education in Hungary
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Hungary's achievements in
       <a href="/wiki/Science" title="Science">
        science
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Technology" title="Technology">
        technology
       </a>
       have been significant, and
       <a href="/wiki/Research_and_development" title="Research and development">
        research and development
       </a>
       efforts form an integral part of the
       <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Hungary" title="Economy of Hungary">
        country's economy
       </a>
       . Hungary spent 1.4% of its gross domestic product (GDP) on civil
       <a href="/wiki/Research_and_development" title="Research and development">
        research and development
       </a>
       in 2015, which is the
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_research_and_development_spending" title="List of countries by research and development spending">
        25th highest ratio in the world
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:0_164-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-:0-164">
         [164]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Hungary ranks 32nd among the most innovative countries in the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bloomberg_Innovation_Index" title="Bloomberg Innovation Index">
        Bloomberg Innovation Index
       </a>
       , standing before
       <a href="/wiki/Hong_Kong" title="Hong Kong">
        Hong Kong
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Iceland" title="Iceland">
        Iceland
       </a>
       or
       <a href="/wiki/Malta" title="Malta">
        Malta
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-165">
        <a href="#cite_note-165">
         [165]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Global_Innovation_Index" title="Global Innovation Index">
        Global Innovation Index
       </a>
       places Hungary 33th among the countries of the world in 2016.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-166">
        <a href="#cite_note-166">
         [166]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 2014, Hungary counted 2,651 full-time equivalent researchers per million inhabitants, steadily increasing from 2,131 in 2010 and compares with 3,984 in the US or 4,380 in Germany.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-167">
        <a href="#cite_note-167">
         [167]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Hungary's
       <a href="/wiki/High_tech" title="High tech">
        high technology
       </a>
       industry has benefited from both the country's skilled workforce and the strong presence of foreign high-tech firms and
       <a href="/wiki/Research_center" title="Research center">
        research centres
       </a>
       . Hungary also has one of the highest rates of filed
       <a href="/wiki/Patent" title="Patent">
        patents
       </a>
       , the 6th highest ratio of high-tech and medium high-tech output in the total industrual output, the 12th highest research
       <a href="/wiki/Foreign_direct_investment" title="Foreign direct investment">
        FDI
       </a>
       inflow, placed 14th in research talent in business enterprise and has the 17th best overall innovation efficiency ratio in the world.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-168">
        <a href="#cite_note-168">
         [168]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The key actor of research and development in Hungary is the National Research, Development and Innovation Office (NRDI Office), which is a national strategic and
       <a href="/wiki/Funding_of_science" title="Funding of science">
        funding agency for scientific research, development and innovation
       </a>
       , the primary source of advice on RDI policy for the
       <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Hungary" title="Government of Hungary">
        Hungarian Government
       </a>
       , and the primary RDI funding agency. Its role is to develop RDI policy and ensure that Hungary adequately invest in RDI by funding excellent research and supporting innovation to increase competitiveness and to prepare the RDI strategy of the Hungarian Government, to handle the National Research, Development and Innovation Fund, and represents the Hungarian Government and a Hungarian RDI community in international organizations.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-169">
        <a href="#cite_note-169">
         [169]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Scientific research in the country is supported partly by industry and partly by the state, through the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_universities_in_Hungary" title="List of universities in Hungary">
        network of Hungarian universities
       </a>
       and by scientific state-institutions such as
       <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_Academy_of_Sciences" title="Hungarian Academy of Sciences">
        Hungarian Academy of Sciences
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-170">
        <a href="#cite_note-170">
         [170]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-171">
        <a href="#cite_note-171">
         [171]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Hungary has been the home of some of the most prominent researchers in various scientific disciplines, notably
       <a href="/wiki/Physics" title="Physics">
        physics
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Mathematics" title="Mathematics">
        mathematics
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Chemistry" title="Chemistry">
        chemistry
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Engineering" title="Engineering">
        engineering
       </a>
       .
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_Hungarian_Nobel_laureates" title="List of Hungarian Nobel laureates">
        13 Hungarian scientists have received the Nobel Prize yet.
       </a>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-172">
        <a href="#cite_note-172">
         [172]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Until 2012 three individuals: Csoma,
       <a href="/wiki/J%C3%A1nos_Bolyai" title="János Bolyai">
        János Bolyai
       </a>
       and Tihanyi were included in the UNESCO Memory of the world register as well as the collective contributions:
       <a href="/wiki/Tabula_Hungariae" title="Tabula Hungariae">
        Tabula Hungariae
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Bibliotheca_Corviniana" title="Bibliotheca Corviniana">
        Bibliotheca Corviniana
       </a>
       . Contemporary, internationally well-known Hungarian scientists include: mathematician
       <a href="/wiki/L%C3%A1szl%C3%B3_Lov%C3%A1sz" title="László Lovász">
        László Lovász
       </a>
       , physicist
       <a href="/wiki/Albert-L%C3%A1szl%C3%B3_Barab%C3%A1si" title="Albert-László Barabási">
        Albert-László Barabási
       </a>
       , physicist
       <a href="/wiki/Ferenc_Krausz" title="Ferenc Krausz">
        Ferenc Krausz
       </a>
       , and biochemist
       <a href="/wiki/%C3%81rp%C3%A1d_Pusztai" title="Árpád Pusztai">
        Árpád Pusztai
       </a>
       . Hungary is famous for its excellent
       <a href="/wiki/Mathematics_education" title="Mathematics education">
        mathematics education
       </a>
       which has trained numerous outstanding scientists. Famous Hungarian mathematicians include father
       <a href="/wiki/Farkas_Bolyai" title="Farkas Bolyai">
        Farkas Bolyai
       </a>
       and son
       <a href="/wiki/J%C3%A1nos_Bolyai" title="János Bolyai">
        János Bolyai
       </a>
       , who was one of the founders of
       <a href="/wiki/Non-Euclidean_geometry" title="Non-Euclidean geometry">
        non-Euclidean geometry
       </a>
       ;
       <a href="/wiki/Paul_Erd%C5%91s" title="Paul Erdős">
        Paul Erdős
       </a>
       , famed for publishing in over forty languages and whose
       <a href="/wiki/Erd%C5%91s_number" title="Erdős number">
        Erdős numbers
       </a>
       are still tracked, and
       <a href="/wiki/John_von_Neumann" title="John von Neumann">
        John von Neumann
       </a>
       , a key contributor in the fields of
       <a href="/wiki/Quantum_mechanics" title="Quantum mechanics">
        quantum mechanics
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Game_theory" title="Game theory">
        game theory
       </a>
       , a pioneer of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Digital_computing" title="Digital computing">
        digital computing
       </a>
       , and the chief mathematician in the
       <a href="/wiki/Manhattan_Project" title="Manhattan Project">
        Manhattan Project
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Transport">
        Transport
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hungary&amp;action=edit&amp;section=25" title="Edit section: Transport">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_Hungary" title="Transport in Hungary">
        Transport in Hungary
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Esztergom.desiro.JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1088" data-file-width="2271" height="105" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Esztergom.desiro.JPG/220px-Esztergom.desiro.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Esztergom.desiro.JPG/330px-Esztergom.desiro.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Esztergom.desiro.JPG/440px-Esztergom.desiro.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Esztergom.desiro.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Siemens_Desiro" title="Siemens Desiro">
          Siemens Desiro
         </a>
         on
         <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_State_Railways" title="Hungarian State Railways">
          Hungarian State Railways
         </a>
         network, which is
         <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_rail_transport_network_size" title="List of countries by rail transport network size">
          one of the densest in the world
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Hungary has a highly developed road, railway, air and water transport system. Budapest, the capital, serves as an important hub for the
       <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_State_Railways" title="Hungarian State Railways">
        Hungarian railway system
       </a>
       (
       <i>
        MÁV
       </i>
       ). The capital is served by three large train stations called
       <i>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eastern_Railway_Station_(Budapest)" title="Eastern Railway Station (Budapest)">
         Keleti
        </a>
       </i>
       (Eastern),
       <i>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Western_Railway_Station_(Budapest)" title="Western Railway Station (Budapest)">
         Nyugati
        </a>
       </i>
       (Western), and
       <i>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Southern_Railway_Station_(Budapest)" title="Southern Railway Station (Budapest)">
         Déli
        </a>
       </i>
       (Southern)
       <i>
        pályaudvar
       </i>
       s.
       <a href="/wiki/Szolnok" title="Szolnok">
        Szolnok
       </a>
       is the most important railway hub outside Budapest, while
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tiszai_Railway_Station" title="Tiszai Railway Station">
        Tiszai Railway Station
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Miskolc" title="Miskolc">
        Miskolc
       </a>
       and the main stations of
       <a href="/wiki/Szombathely" title="Szombathely">
        Szombathely
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Gy%C5%91r" title="Győr">
        Győr
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Szeged" title="Szeged">
        Szeged
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Sz%C3%A9kesfeh%C3%A9rv%C3%A1r" title="Székesfehérvár">
        Székesfehérvár
       </a>
       are also key to the network.
      </p>
      <p>
       Budapest,
       <a href="/wiki/Debrecen" title="Debrecen">
        Debrecen
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Miskolc" title="Miskolc">
        Miskolc
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Szeged" title="Szeged">
        Szeged
       </a>
       have tram networks. The
       <a href="/wiki/Budapest_Metro" title="Budapest Metro">
        Budapest Metro
       </a>
       is the second-oldest underground
       <a href="/wiki/Rapid_transit" title="Rapid transit">
        metro
       </a>
       system in the world; its
       <a href="/wiki/Line_1_(Budapest_Metro)" title="Line 1 (Budapest Metro)">
        Line 1
       </a>
       dates from 1896 and is a
       <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">
        World Heritage Site
       </a>
       . The system consists of four lines. A
       <a href="/wiki/Regional_rail" title="Regional rail">
        commuter rail
       </a>
       system,
       <i>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/H%C3%89V" title="HÉV">
         HÉV
        </a>
       </i>
       , operates in the Budapest metropolitan area. Hungary has a total length of approximately 1,314 km (816.48 mi) motorways (
       <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_language" title="Hungarian language">
        Hungarian
       </a>
       :
       <i>
        <span lang="hu">
         autópálya
        </span>
       </i>
       ). Motorway sections are being added to the existing network, which already connects many major economically important cities to the capital. The most important port is Budapest. Other important ones include
       <a href="/wiki/Duna%C3%BAjv%C3%A1ros" title="Dunaújváros">
        Dunaújváros
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Baja,_Hungary" title="Baja, Hungary">
        Baja
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       There are five international airports in Hungary:
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Budapest_Liszt_Ferenc_International_Airport" title="Budapest Liszt Ferenc International Airport">
        Budapest Liszt Ferenc
       </a>
       (informally called "Ferihegy" after its previous name),
       <a href="/wiki/Debrecen_International_Airport" title="Debrecen International Airport">
        Debrecen
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/S%C3%A1rmell%C3%A9k_International_Airport" title="Sármellék International Airport">
        Sármellék
       </a>
       (also called Hévíz-Balaton Airport),
       <a href="/wiki/Gy%C5%91r-P%C3%A9r_International_Airport" title="Győr-Pér International Airport">
        Győr-Pér
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/P%C3%A9cs-Pog%C3%A1ny_International_Airport" title="Pécs-Pogány International Airport">
        Pécs-Pogány
       </a>
       . The national carrier,
       <a href="/wiki/Mal%C3%A9v_Hungarian_Airlines" title="Malév Hungarian Airlines">
        MALÉV
       </a>
       , operated flights to over 60, mostly European cities, but ceased operations in 2012. Low-budget airline
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/WizzAir" title="WizzAir">
        WizzAir
       </a>
       is based in Hungary, at Ferihegy.
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">
        Demographics
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hungary&amp;action=edit&amp;section=26" title="Edit section: Demographics">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Hungary" title="Demographics of Hungary">
        Demographics of Hungary
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Hungarians" title="Hungarians">
        Hungarians
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Magyars_900-1980.png">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="604" data-file-width="970" height="137" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/Magyars_900-1980.png/220px-Magyars_900-1980.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/Magyars_900-1980.png/330px-Magyars_900-1980.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/Magyars_900-1980.png/440px-Magyars_900-1980.png 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Magyars_900-1980.png" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Hungarians" title="Hungarians">
          Hungarian population
         </a>
         development in the last thousand years
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Hungary's population was 9,937,628 according to the 2011
       <a href="/wiki/Census" title="Census">
        census
       </a>
       , thus the country is the
       <a href="/wiki/Central_and_Eastern_Europe" title="Central and Eastern Europe">
        5th most populous in the Central and Eastern European region
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_the_European_Union" title="Demographics of the European Union">
        medium-sized member state of the European Union
       </a>
       .
       <a href="/wiki/Population_density" title="Population density">
        Population density
       </a>
       stands at 107 inhabitants per square kilometre, which is about two times higher than the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_sovereign_states_and_dependent_territories_by_population_density" title="List of sovereign states and dependent territories by population density">
        world average
       </a>
       . More than one quarter of the population lived in the
       <a href="/wiki/Budapest_metropolitan_area" title="Budapest metropolitan area">
        Budapest metropolitan area
       </a>
       , 6,903,858 people (69.5%) in
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_and_towns_of_Hungary" title="List of cities and towns of Hungary">
        cities and towns
       </a>
       overall.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Census2011_3-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Census2011-3">
         [3]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Like most other European countries, Hungary is experiencing
       <a href="/wiki/Sub-replacement_fertility" title="Sub-replacement fertility">
        sub-replacement fertility
       </a>
       , with the
       <a href="/wiki/Total_fertility_rate" title="Total fertility rate">
        total fertility rate
       </a>
       estimated at 1.43 children born/woman in 2015, lower than the replacement rate of 2.1.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-173">
        <a href="#cite_note-173">
         [173]
        </a>
       </sup>
       This is leading to gradual population decline and rapid aging. The recent decrease in birth rate occurred in the 1990s; dropping from 1.87 in 1990 to 1.28 in 1999.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-174">
        <a href="#cite_note-174">
         [174]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 2011, the conservative government began a program to increase the birth rate with a focus on ethnic Magyars by reinstating 3 year maternity leave as well as boosting part-time jobs. The birth rate has gradually increased from 1.27 children born/woman in 2011.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-175">
        <a href="#cite_note-175">
         [175]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The natural decrease in the first 10 months of 2016 was only 25,828 which was 8,162 less than the corresponding period in 2015.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-176">
        <a href="#cite_note-176">
         [176]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 2015, 47.9% of births were to unmarried women.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-177">
        <a href="#cite_note-177">
         [177]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Life_expectancy" title="Life expectancy">
        Life expectancy
       </a>
       was 71.96 years for men and 79.62 years for women in 2015,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-178">
        <a href="#cite_note-178">
         [178]
        </a>
       </sup>
       growing continuously since the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/End_of_Communism_in_Hungary_(1989)" title="End of Communism in Hungary (1989)">
        fall of Communism
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-179">
        <a href="#cite_note-179">
         [179]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Two sizable groups of people are referred to as "national minorities" because their ancestors have lived in their respective regions for centuries in Hungary. There is a
       <a href="/wiki/Germans_of_Hungary" title="Germans of Hungary">
        German minority
       </a>
       (about 130,000) living throughout the whole country, and there is a
       <a href="/wiki/Romani_people_in_Hungary" title="Romani people in Hungary">
        Romani minority
       </a>
       (about 300,000) that mainly resides in
       <a href="/wiki/Northern_Hungary" title="Northern Hungary">
        the northern part of the country
       </a>
       . According to the 2011 census, there were 8,014,029 (80.7%)
       <a href="/wiki/Hungarians" title="Hungarians">
        Hungarians
       </a>
       , 608,957 (6.1%)
       <a href="/wiki/Romani_people" title="Romani people">
        Romani
       </a>
       , 131,951 (1.3%)
       <a href="/wiki/Germans" title="Germans">
        Germans
       </a>
       , 29,647 (0.3%)
       <a href="/wiki/Slovaks" title="Slovaks">
        Slovaks
       </a>
       , 26,345 (0.3%)
       <a href="/wiki/Romanians" title="Romanians">
        Romanians
       </a>
       , and 23,561 (0.2%)
       <a href="/wiki/Croats" title="Croats">
        Croats
       </a>
       in Hungary. 1,455,883 people (14.7% of the total population) did not declare their ethnicity. Thus, Hungarians made up more than 90% of people who declared their ethnicity.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Census2011det_4-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Census2011det-4">
         [4]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In Hungary, people can declare more than one ethnicity, so the sum of ethnicities is higher than the total population.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-180">
        <a href="#cite_note-180">
         [180]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Today approximately
       <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_diaspora" title="Hungarian diaspora">
        5 million Hungarians live outside Hungary
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <table class="infobox" style="width:100%; text-align:center; font-size:85%">

           </a>
           of Hungary
          </b>
         </div>

      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Languages">
        Languages
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hungary&amp;action=edit&amp;section=27" title="Edit section: Languages">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_language" title="Hungarian language">
        Hungarian language
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Hungary" title="Languages of Hungary">
        Languages of Hungary
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Dist_of_hu_lang_europe.svg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="438" data-file-width="688" height="140" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Dist_of_hu_lang_europe.svg/220px-Dist_of_hu_lang_europe.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Dist_of_hu_lang_europe.svg/330px-Dist_of_hu_lang_europe.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Dist_of_hu_lang_europe.svg/440px-Dist_of_hu_lang_europe.svg.png 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Dist_of_hu_lang_europe.svg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Present-day regions in Europe where Hungarian is the majority language
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_language" title="Hungarian language">
        Hungarian
       </a>
       is the
       <a href="/wiki/Official_language" title="Official language">
        official
       </a>
       and predominant spoken language in Hungary. Hungarian is the
       <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Europe" title="Languages of Europe">
        13th most widely spoken first language in Europe
       </a>
       with around 13 million native speakers and it is one of 24 official and working languages of the European Union.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-181">
        <a href="#cite_note-181">
         [181]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Outside Hungary it is also spoken by communities of
       <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_diaspora" title="Hungarian diaspora">
        Hungarian people in neighbouring countries and by Hungarian diaspora communities worldwide
       </a>
       . According to the 2011 census, 9,896,333 people (99.6%) speak Hungarian in Hungary, of whom 9,827,875 people (99%) speak it as a
       <a href="/wiki/First_language" title="First language">
        first language
       </a>
       , while 68,458 people (0.7%) speak it as a
       <a href="/wiki/Second_language" title="Second language">
        second language
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Census2011det_4-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-Census2011det-4">
         [4]
        </a>
       </sup>
       English (1,589,180 speakers, 16.0%), and German (1,111,997 speakers, 11.2%) are the most widely spoken
       <a href="/wiki/Foreign_language" title="Foreign language">
        foreign languages
       </a>
       , while there are several recognized minority languages in Hungary (
       <a href="/wiki/Croatian_language" title="Croatian language">
        Croatian
       </a>
       , German,
       <a href="/wiki/Romanian_language" title="Romanian language">
        Romanian
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Romani_language" title="Romani language">
        Romani
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Serbian_language" title="Serbian language">
        Serbian
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Slovak_language" title="Slovak language">
        Slovak
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Slovenian_language" title="Slovenian language">
        Slovenian
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_language" title="Ukrainian language">
        Ukrainian
       </a>
       ).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Census2011_3-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-Census2011-3">
         [3]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Hungarian (Magyar) is a member of the
       <a href="/wiki/Uralic_languages" title="Uralic languages">
        Uralic language family
       </a>
       , unrelated to any neighboring language and distantly related to
       <a href="/wiki/Finnish_language" title="Finnish language">
        Finnish
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Estonian_language" title="Estonian language">
        Estonian
       </a>
       . It is the largest of the Uralic languages in terms of the number of speakers and the only one spoken in
       <a href="/wiki/Central_Europe" title="Central Europe">
        Central Europe
       </a>
       . There are sizable populations of Hungarian speakers in Romania, the Czech and Slovak Republics, the former Yugoslavia, Ukraine, Israel, and the U.S. Smaller groups of Hungarian speakers live in Canada, Slovenia, and Austria, but also in Australia, Brazil, Argentina, Mexico, Venezuela and Chile. Standard Hungarian is based on the variety spoken in the capital of
       <a href="/wiki/Budapest" title="Budapest">
        Budapest
       </a>
       , although use of the standard dialect is enforced, Hungarian has a number of urban and rural
       <a href="/wiki/Dialect" title="Dialect">
        dialects
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">
        Religion
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hungary&amp;action=edit&amp;section=28" title="Edit section: Religion">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Hungary" title="Religion in Hungary">
        Religion in Hungary
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Esztergom.bazilika.lights.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1704" data-file-width="2272" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Esztergom.bazilika.lights.jpg/220px-Esztergom.bazilika.lights.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Esztergom.bazilika.lights.jpg/330px-Esztergom.bazilika.lights.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Esztergom.bazilika.lights.jpg/440px-Esztergom.bazilika.lights.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Esztergom.bazilika.lights.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Esztergom_Basilica" title="Esztergom Basilica">
          Esztergom Basilica
         </a>
         , the largest
         <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_in_Hungary" title="Catholic Church in Hungary">
          Catholic Church in Hungary
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Debreceni_reform%C3%A1tus_nagytemplom.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1536" data-file-width="2048" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Debreceni_reform%C3%A1tus_nagytemplom.jpg/220px-Debreceni_reform%C3%A1tus_nagytemplom.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Debreceni_reform%C3%A1tus_nagytemplom.jpg/330px-Debreceni_reform%C3%A1tus_nagytemplom.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Debreceni_reform%C3%A1tus_nagytemplom.jpg/440px-Debreceni_reform%C3%A1tus_nagytemplom.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Debreceni_reform%C3%A1tus_nagytemplom.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The
         <a href="/wiki/Reformed_Great_Church_of_Debrecen" title="Reformed Great Church of Debrecen">
          Reformed Great Church of Debrecen
         </a>
         , a symbol of the
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hungarian_Reformed_Church" title="Hungarian Reformed Church">
          Hungarian Reformed Church
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Hungary is a historically
       <a href="/wiki/Christian" title="Christian">
        Christian
       </a>
       country. Hungarian historiography identifies the foundation of the Hungarian state with
       <a href="/wiki/Stephen_I_of_Hungary" title="Stephen I of Hungary">
        Stephen I's
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Baptism" title="Baptism">
        baptism
       </a>
       and coronation with the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Szentkorona" title="Szentkorona">
        Holy Crown
       </a>
       in A.D. 1000. Stephen promulgated
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Roman_Catholicism" title="Roman Catholicism">
        Roman Catholicism
       </a>
       as the state religion, and his successors were traditionally known as the
       <a href="/wiki/Apostolic_King" title="Apostolic King">
        Apostolic Kings
       </a>
       . The
       <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_in_Hungary" title="Catholic Church in Hungary">
        Catholic Church in Hungary
       </a>
       remained strong through the centuries, and the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Archbishop_of_Esztergom" title="Archbishop of Esztergom">
        Archbishop of Esztergom
       </a>
       was granted extraordinary temporal privileges as
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Prince-primate" title="Prince-primate">
        prince-primate
       </a>
       (
       <i>
        hercegprímás
       </i>
       ) of Hungary. Contemporary Hungary has no
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Official_religion" title="Official religion">
        official religion
       </a>
       . The constitution "recognizes Christianity's nation-building role"
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-182">
        <a href="#cite_note-182">
         [182]
        </a>
       </sup>
       while affirming
       <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_religion" title="Freedom of religion">
        freedom of religion
       </a>
       as a fundamental right.
      </p>
      <p>
       With the onset of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Protestant_Reformation" title="Protestant Reformation">
        Protestant Reformation
       </a>
       , most Hungarians took up first
       <a href="/wiki/Lutheranism" title="Lutheranism">
        Lutheranism
       </a>
       , then soon afterwards
       <a href="/wiki/Calvinism" title="Calvinism">
        Calvinism
       </a>
       . In the second half of the 16th century, however,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jesuits" title="Jesuits">
        Jesuits
       </a>
       led a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Counterreformation" title="Counterreformation">
        Counterreformation
       </a>
       campaign and the population once again became predominantly Catholic. However, in comparison to other European regions where such efforts were undertaken, it was not at all successful. Some localities all over Hungary are still majority Protestant (either Lutheran or Reformed) and the country's eastern regions, especially around
       <a href="/wiki/Debrecen" title="Debrecen">
        Debrecen
       </a>
       (the "Calvinist Rome"), remain predominantly
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Reformed" title="Reformed">
        Reformed
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-183">
        <a href="#cite_note-183">
         [183]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Erd%C3%A9ly" title="Erdély">
        Erdély
       </a>
       (Transylvania), historically part of Hungary, also remained Protestant.
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church" title="Eastern Orthodox Church">
        Orthodox Christianity
       </a>
       in Hungary is associated with the country's ethnic minorities:
       <a href="/wiki/Romanians" title="Romanians">
        Romanians
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Rusyns" title="Rusyns">
        Rusyns
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Ukrainians" title="Ukrainians">
        Ukrainians
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Serbs" title="Serbs">
        Serbs
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       Historically, Hungary was home to a significant Jewish community. Some
       <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_in_Hungary" title="History of the Jews in Hungary">
        Hungarian Jews
       </a>
