       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Upper-Hungary&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Upper-Hungary (page does not exist)">
        Upper-Hungary
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tokaj-Hegyalja" title="Tokaj-Hegyalja">
        Tokaj-Hegyalja
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       Hungarian wine regions offer a great variety of styles: the main products of the country are elegant and full-bodied dry whites with good acidity, although complex sweet whites (Tokaj), elegant (
       <a href="/wiki/Eger" title="Eger">
        Eger
       </a>
       ) and full-bodied robust reds (
       <a href="/wiki/Vill%C3%A1ny" title="Villány">
        Villány
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Szeksz%C3%A1rd" title="Szekszárd">
        Szekszárd
       </a>
       ). The main varieties are:
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Olaszrizling" title="Olaszrizling">
        Olaszrizling
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/H%C3%A1rslevel%C5%B1" title="Hárslevelű">
        Hárslevelű
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Furmint" title="Furmint">
        Furmint
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Pinot_gris" title="Pinot gris">
        Pinot gris
       </a>
       or Szürkebarát,
       <a href="/wiki/Chardonnay" title="Chardonnay">
        Chardonnay
       </a>
       (whites),
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/K%C3%A9kfrankos" title="Kékfrankos">
        Kékfrankos
       </a>
       (or Blaufrankisch in German),
       <a href="/wiki/Kadarka" title="Kadarka">
        Kadarka
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Portugieser" title="Portugieser">
        Portugieser
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Zweigelt" title="Zweigelt">
        Zweigelt
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cabernet_sauvignon" title="Cabernet sauvignon">
        Cabernet sauvignon
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cabernet_franc" title="Cabernet franc">
        Cabernet franc
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Merlot" title="Merlot">
        Merlot
       </a>
       . The most famous wines from Hungary are
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tokaji_Asz%C3%BA" title="Tokaji Aszú">
        Tokaji Aszú
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Egri_Bikav%C3%A9r" title="Egri Bikavér">
        Egri Bikavér
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-206">
        <a href="#cite_note-206">
         [206]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-207">
        <a href="#cite_note-207">
         [207]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Tokaji" title="Tokaji">
        Tokaji
       </a>
       , meaning "of Tokaj", or "from Tokaj" in Hungarian, is used to label wines from the wine region of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tokaj-Hegyalja" title="Tokaj-Hegyalja">
        Tokaj-Hegyalja
       </a>
       . Tokaji wine has received accolades from numerous great writers and composers including
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Beethoven" title="Beethoven">
        Beethoven
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Liszt" title="Liszt">
        Liszt
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Schubert" title="Schubert">
        Schubert
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Goethe" title="Goethe">
        Goethe
       </a>
       ;
       <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Haydn" title="Joseph Haydn">
        Joseph Haydn
       </a>
       's favorite wine was a Tokaji.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-royal_tokaji_208-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-royal_tokaji-208">
         [208]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Louis_XV" title="Louis XV">
        Louis XV
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Frederick_the_Great" title="Frederick the Great">
        Frederick the Great
       </a>
       tried to outdo one another when they entertained guests with Tokaji. Napoleon III, the last Emperor of France, ordered 30–40 barrels of Tokaji at the French Royal Court every year. Gustav III, King of Sweden, loved Tokaji.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-royal_tokaji_208-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-royal_tokaji-208">
         [208]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In Russia, customers included Peter the Great and Empress Elizabeth, while Catherine the Great actually established a Russian garrison in the town of Tokaj with the aim of assuring regular wine deliveries to St. Petersburg.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-royal_tokaji_208-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-royal_tokaji-208">
         [208]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       For over 150 years, a blend of 40 Hungarian herbs has been used to create the liqueur
       <a href="/wiki/Unicum" title="Unicum">
        Unicum
       </a>
       . Unicum is a bitter, dark-coloured liqueur that can be drunk as an apéritif or after a meal, thus helping the digestion.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-209">
        <a href="#cite_note-209">
         [209]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Recreation">
        Recreation
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hungary&amp;action=edit&amp;section=36" title="Edit section: Recreation">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:H%C3%A9v%C3%ADz.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="800" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/H%C3%A9v%C3%ADz.jpg/220px-H%C3%A9v%C3%ADz.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/H%C3%A9v%C3%ADz.jpg/330px-H%C3%A9v%C3%ADz.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/H%C3%A9v%C3%ADz.jpg/440px-H%C3%A9v%C3%ADz.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:H%C3%A9v%C3%ADz.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Lake_H%C3%A9v%C3%ADz" title="Lake Hévíz">
          Lake Hévíz
         </a>
         , the largest thermal lake in Europe
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Hungary is a land of
       <a href="/wiki/Thermal" title="Thermal">
        thermal
       </a>
       water. A passion for spa culture and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hungarian_history" title="Hungarian history">
        Hungarian history
       </a>
       have been connected from the very beginning. Hungarian spas feature
       <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Rome" title="Ancient Rome">
        Roman
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Greek_architecture" title="Greek architecture">
        Greek
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_Turkey" title="Architecture of Turkey">
        Turkish
       </a>
       , and northern country architectural elements.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-210">
        <a href="#cite_note-210">
         [210]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Because of an advantageous geographical location, good quality thermal water can be found in great quantities on over 80% of Hungary's territory. Approximately 1,500 thermal springs can be found in Hungary (more than 100 just in the Capital area). There are approximately 450 public baths in Hungary.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-211">
        <a href="#cite_note-211">
         [211]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Rome" title="Ancient Rome">
        Romans
       </a>
       heralded the first age of spas in Hungary. The remains of their bath complexes are still to be seen in
       <a href="/wiki/%C3%93buda" title="Óbuda">
        Óbuda
       </a>
       . Spa culture was revived during the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkish_Invasion" title="Turkish Invasion">
        Turkish Invasion
       </a>
       and the thermal springs of
       <a href="/wiki/Buda" title="Buda">
        Buda
       </a>
       were used for the construction of a number of bathhouses, some of which such as (
       <a href="/wiki/Kir%C3%A1ly_Baths" title="Király Baths">
        Király Baths
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Rudas_Baths" title="Rudas Baths">
        Rudas Baths
       </a>
       ) are still functioning.
      </p>
      <p>
       In the 19th century, the advancement in deep drilling and medical science provided the springboard for a further leap in bathing culture. Grand spas such as
       <a href="/wiki/Gell%C3%A9rt_Baths" title="Gellért Baths">
        Gellért Baths
       </a>
       , Lukács Baths,
       <a href="/wiki/Margaret_Island" title="Margaret Island">
        Margaret Island
       </a>
       , and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sz%C3%A9chenyi_Medicinal_Bath" title="Széchenyi Medicinal Bath">
        Széchenyi Medicinal Bath
       </a>
       are a reflection of this resurgence in popularity. The Széchenyi Thermal Bath is the largest spa complex in Europe and it was the first thermal bath built in the Pest side of Budapest.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-212">
        <a href="#cite_note-212">
         [212]
        </a>
       </sup>
       This building is a noted example of modern Renaissance Style. Located on the Buda side of Budapest, the Gellért spa is the most famous and luxurious thermal complex of the capital city.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-213">
        <a href="#cite_note-213">
         [213]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Folk_art">
        Folk art
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hungary&amp;action=edit&amp;section=37" title="Edit section: Folk art">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Voivodina_Hungarians_national_costume_and_dance_6.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1340" data-file-width="1302" height="226" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/Voivodina_Hungarians_national_costume_and_dance_6.jpg/220px-Voivodina_Hungarians_national_costume_and_dance_6.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/Voivodina_Hungarians_national_costume_and_dance_6.jpg/330px-Voivodina_Hungarians_national_costume_and_dance_6.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/Voivodina_Hungarians_national_costume_and_dance_6.jpg/440px-Voivodina_Hungarians_national_costume_and_dance_6.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Voivodina_Hungarians_national_costume_and_dance_6.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Hungarians dancing
         <a href="/wiki/Cs%C3%A1rd%C3%A1s" title="Csárdás">
          csárdás
         </a>
         in traditional garments / folk costumes
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Ugr%C3%B3s" title="Ugrós">
        Ugrós
       </a>
       (Jumping dances): Old style dances dating back to the
       <a href="/wiki/Middle_Ages" title="Middle Ages">
        Middle Ages
       </a>
       . Solo or couple dances accompanied by old style music, shepherd and other solo man's dances from
       <a href="/wiki/Transylvania" title="Transylvania">
        Transylvania
       </a>
       , and marching dances along with remnants of medieval weapon dances belong in this group.
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Karik%C3%A1z%C3%B3" title="Karikázó">
        Karikázó
       </a>
       : a circle dance performed by women only accompanied by singing of folksongs.
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Cs%C3%A1rd%C3%A1s" title="Csárdás">
        Csárdás
       </a>
       : New style dances developed in the 18–19th centuries is the Hungarian name for the national dances, with Hungarian embroidered costumes and energetic music. From the men's intricate bootslapping dances to the ancient women's circle dances, Csárdás demonstrates the infectious exuberance of the Hungarian folk dancing still celebrated in the villages.
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Verbunkos" title="Verbunkos">
        Verbunkos
       </a>
       : a solo man's dance evolved from the recruiting performances of the
       <a href="/wiki/Austria-Hungary" title="Austria-Hungary">
        Austro-Hungarian
       </a>
       army.
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Leg%C3%A9nyes" title="Legényes">
        Legényes
       </a>
       is a men's solo dance done by the ethnic Hungarian people living in the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kalotaszeg" title="Kalotaszeg">
        Kalotaszeg
       </a>
       region of Transylvania. Although usually danced by young men, it can be also danced by older men. The dance is generally performed freestyle by one dancer at a time in front of a band. Women participate in the dance by standing in lines to the side, and singing or shouting verses while the men dance. Each man performs a number of points (dance phrases), typically four to eight without repetition. Each point consists of four parts, each lasting four counts. The first part is usually the same for everyone (there are only a few variations).
      </p>
      <p>
       It was in the beginning of the 18th-century that the present style of Hungarian folk art took shape, incorporating both
       <a href="/wiki/Renaissance" title="Renaissance">
        Renaissance
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Baroque" title="Baroque">
        Baroque
       </a>
       elements, depending on the area, as well as Persian
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sassanide" title="Sassanide">
        Sassanide
       </a>
       influences. Flowers and leaves, sometimes a bird or a spiral ornament, are the principal decorative themes. The most frequent ornament is a flower with a centerpiece resembling the eye of a peacock's feather.
      </p>
      <p>
       Nearly all the manifestations of folk art practiced elsewhere in Europe also flourished among the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hungarian_people" title="Hungarian people">
        Magyar
       </a>
       peasantry at one time or another, their ceramics and textile being the most highly developed of all.
      </p>
      <p>
       The finest achievements in their textile arts are the embroideries which vary from region to region. Those of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kalotaszeg" title="Kalotaszeg">
        Kalotaszeg
       </a>
       in Transylvania are charming products of Oriental design, sewn chiefly in a single color – red, blue, or black. Soft in line, the embroideries are applied on altar cloths, pillow-cases and sheets.
      </p>
      <p>
       In Hungary proper, Sárköz in
       <a href="/wiki/Transdanubia" title="Transdanubia">
        Transdanubia
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/Mez%C5%91k%C3%B6vesd" title="Mezőkövesd">
        Matyóföld
       </a>
       in the
       <a href="/wiki/Great_Hungarian_Plain" title="Great Hungarian Plain">
        Great Hungarian Plain
       </a>
       produce the finest embroideries. In the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tolna_(county)" title="Tolna (county)">
        Sárköz
       </a>
       region the women's caps show black and white designs as delicate as lace, and give evidence of the people's wonderfully subtle artistic feeling. The embroidery motifs applied to women's wear have also been transposed to tablecloths and runners suitable for modern use as wall decorations.
      </p>
      <p>
       These vessels, made of black clay, reflect more than three hundred years of traditional Transdanubian folk patterns and shapes. No two are precisely alike, since all work is done by hand, including both the shaping and the decorating. The imprints are made by the thumb or a finger of the ceramist who makes the piece.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Porcelain">
        Porcelain
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hungary&amp;action=edit&amp;section=38" title="Edit section: Porcelain">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Herend_Porcelain" title="Herend Porcelain">
        Herend Porcelain
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Zsolnay" title="Zsolnay">
        Zsolnay
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Founded in 1826,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Herend_Porcelain" title="Herend Porcelain">
        Herend Porcelain
       </a>
       is one of the world's largest ceramic factories, specializing in luxury hand painted and gilded
       <a href="/wiki/Porcelain" title="Porcelain">
        porcelain
       </a>
       . In the mid-19th century it was purveyor to the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Habsburg_Dynasty" title="Habsburg Dynasty">
        Habsburg Dynasty
       </a>
       and aristocratic customers throughout Europe. Many of its classic patterns are still in production. After the fall of communism in Hungary, the factory was privatised and is now 75% owned by its management and workers, exporting to over 60 countries of the world.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-214">
        <a href="#cite_note-214">
         [214]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Zsolnay Porcelain Manufacture is a Hungarian manufacturer of porcelain, pottery, ceramics, tiles and stoneware. The company introduced the eosin glazing process and pyrogranite ceramics. The Zsolnay factory was established by Miklós Zsolnay in
       <a href="/wiki/P%C3%A9cs" title="Pécs">
        Pécs
       </a>
       , Hungary, to produce stoneware and ceramics in 1853. In 1863, his son,
       <a href="/wiki/Vilmos_Zsolnay" title="Vilmos Zsolnay">
        Vilmos Zsolnay
       </a>
       (1828–1900) joined the company and became its manager and director after several years. He led the factory to worldwide recognition by demonstrating its innovative products at world fairs and international exhibitions, including the 1873 World Fair in Vienna, then at the 1878 World Fair in Paris, where Zsolnay received a Grand Prix.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Sport">
        Sport
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hungary&amp;action=edit&amp;section=39" title="Edit section: Sport">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/Hungary_at_the_Olympics" title="Hungary at the Olympics">
        Hungary at the Olympics
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Vaterpolo_Hungary_vs_Italy_semifinal_game2.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1936" data-file-width="2592" height="164" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Vaterpolo_Hungary_vs_Italy_semifinal_game2.jpg/220px-Vaterpolo_Hungary_vs_Italy_semifinal_game2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Vaterpolo_Hungary_vs_Italy_semifinal_game2.jpg/330px-Vaterpolo_Hungary_vs_Italy_semifinal_game2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Vaterpolo_Hungary_vs_Italy_semifinal_game2.jpg/440px-Vaterpolo_Hungary_vs_Italy_semifinal_game2.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Vaterpolo_Hungary_vs_Italy_semifinal_game2.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Hungary_men%27s_national_water_polo_team" title="Hungary men's national water polo team">
          Hungary men's national water polo team
         </a>
         is considered among the best in the world, holding the world record for Olympic golds and overall medals
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Groupama_Arena_Budapest_(17267881892).jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3644" data-file-width="5465" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Groupama_Arena_Budapest_%2817267881892%29.jpg/220px-Groupama_Arena_Budapest_%2817267881892%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Groupama_Arena_Budapest_%2817267881892%29.jpg/330px-Groupama_Arena_Budapest_%2817267881892%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Groupama_Arena_Budapest_%2817267881892%29.jpg/440px-Groupama_Arena_Budapest_%2817267881892%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Groupama_Arena_Budapest_(17267881892).jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Groupama_Arena" title="Groupama Arena">
          Groupama Arena
         </a>
         ,
         <a href="/wiki/Ferencv%C3%A1rosi_TC" title="Ferencvárosi TC">
          Ferencvárosi TC
         </a>
         's
         <a href="/wiki/UEFA_stadium_categories" title="UEFA stadium categories">
          UEFA category four stadium
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ferenc_Pusk%C3%A1s_2.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1280" data-file-width="841" height="259" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/Ferenc_Pusk%C3%A1s_2.jpg/170px-Ferenc_Pusk%C3%A1s_2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/Ferenc_Pusk%C3%A1s_2.jpg/255px-Ferenc_Pusk%C3%A1s_2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/Ferenc_Pusk%C3%A1s_2.jpg/340px-Ferenc_Pusk%C3%A1s_2.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ferenc_Pusk%C3%A1s_2.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Ferenc_Pusk%C3%A1s" title="Ferenc Puskás">
          Ferenc Puskás
         </a>
         , the best goalscorer of the 20th century,
         <a href="/wiki/FIFA_Pusk%C3%A1s_Award" title="FIFA Puskás Award">
          FIFA Puskás Award
         </a>
         named after him
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Hungary_at_the_Olympics" title="Hungary at the Olympics">
        Hungarian athletes
       </a>
       have been successful contenders in the
       <a href="/wiki/Olympic_Games" title="Olympic Games">
        Olympic Games
       </a>
       , only seven countries have won more Olympic medals than Hungary, with a total of 497 medals ranking eighth in an
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/All-time_Olympic_Games_medal_count" title="All-time Olympic Games medal count">
        all-time Olympic Games medal count
       </a>
       . Hungary has the third-highest number of
       <a href="/wiki/Olympic_medal" title="Olympic medal">
        Olympic medals
       </a>
       per capita and second-highest number of gold medals per capita in the world.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-215">
        <a href="#cite_note-215">
         [215]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Hungary has historically excelled in Olympic water sports. In
       <a href="/wiki/Water_polo" title="Water polo">
        water polo
       </a>
       the Hungarian team is the
       <a href="/wiki/Water_polo_at_the_Summer_Olympics" title="Water polo at the Summer Olympics">
        leading medal winner by a significant margin
       </a>
       and in
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_Olympic_medalists_in_swimming_(men)" title="List of Olympic medalists in swimming (men)">
        swimming Hungarian men
       </a>
       are fourth most successful overall, while
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_Olympic_medalists_in_swimming_(women)" title="List of Olympic medalists in swimming (women)">
        the women
       </a>
       are eighth most successful overall. They have also seen success in canoeing and kayaking
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Canoeing_and_kayaking_at_the_Summer_Olympics" title="Canoeing and kayaking at the Summer Olympics">
        they are the third most successful overall
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       In 2015 the Assembly of the
       <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_Olympic_Committee" title="Hungarian Olympic Committee">
        Hungarian Olympic Committee
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/General_Assembly_of_Budapest" title="General Assembly of Budapest">
        Assembly of Budapest
       </a>
       decided to bid for the
       <a href="/wiki/2024_Summer_Olympics" title="2024 Summer Olympics">
        2024 Summer Olympics
       </a>
       but eventually awarded to
       <a href="/wiki/Paris" title="Paris">
        Paris
       </a>
       . Budapest has also lost several bids to host the games, in
       <a href="/wiki/1916_Summer_Olympics" title="1916 Summer Olympics">
        1916
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/1920_Summer_Olympics" title="1920 Summer Olympics">
        1920
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/1936_Summer_Olympics" title="1936 Summer Olympics">
        1936
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/1944_Summer_Olympics" title="1944 Summer Olympics">
        1944
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/1960_Summer_Olympics" title="1960 Summer Olympics">
        1960
       </a>
       to
       <a href="/wiki/Berlin" title="Berlin">
        Berlin
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Antwerp" title="Antwerp">
        Antwerp
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/London" title="London">
        London
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Rome" title="Rome">
        Rome
       </a>
       , respectively.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-216">
        <a href="#cite_note-216">
         [216]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-217">
        <a href="#cite_note-217">
         [217]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hungarian_Parliament" title="Hungarian Parliament">
        Hungarian Parliament
       </a>
       also voted to support the bid on 28 January 2016, later Budapest City Council approved list of venues and
       <a href="/wiki/Budapest_bid_for_the_2024_Summer_Olympics" title="Budapest bid for the 2024 Summer Olympics">
        Budapest became an official candidate for the 2024 Summer Olympic Games
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       Hungary hosted many global
       <a href="/wiki/Sport" title="Sport">
        sport
       </a>
       event in the past, among others the
       <a href="/wiki/1997_World_Amateur_Boxing_Championships" title="1997 World Amateur Boxing Championships">
        1997 World Amateur Boxing Championships
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/2000_World_Fencing_Championships" title="2000 World Fencing Championships">
        2000 World Fencing Championships
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/2001_World_Allround_Speed_Skating_Championships" title="2001 World Allround Speed Skating Championships">
        2001 World Allround Speed Skating Championships
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/2008_World_Interuniversity_Games" title="2008 World Interuniversity Games">
        2008 World Interuniversity Games
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/2008_World_Modern_Pentathlon_Championships" title="2008 World Modern Pentathlon Championships">
        2008 World Modern Pentathlon Championships
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/2010_ITU_World_Championship_Series" title="2010 ITU World Championship Series">
        2010 ITU World Championship Series
       </a>
       , 2011
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/IIHF_World_Championship" title="IIHF World Championship">
        IIHF World Championship
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/2013_World_Fencing_Championships" title="2013 World Fencing Championships">
        2013 World Fencing Championships
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/2013_World_Wrestling_Championships" title="2013 World Wrestling Championships">
        2013 World Wrestling Championships
       </a>
       , 2014
       <a href="/wiki/World_Masters_Athletics_Championships" title="World Masters Athletics Championships">
        World Masters Athletics Championships
       </a>
       and will in the future, like
       <a href="/wiki/2017_World_Aquatics_Championships" title="2017 World Aquatics Championships">
        2017 World Aquatics Championships
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/2017_World_Judo_Championships" title="2017 World Judo Championships">
        2017 World Judo Championships
       </a>
       , only in the last two decade. Besides these, Hungary was the home of many European-level tournaments, like
       <a href="/wiki/2006_European_Aquatics_Championships" title="2006 European Aquatics Championships">
        2006 European Aquatics Championships
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/2010_European_Aquatics_Championships" title="2010 European Aquatics Championships">
        2010 European Aquatics Championships
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/2013_European_Judo_Championships" title="2013 European Judo Championships">
        2013 European Judo Championships
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/2013_European_Karate_Championships" title="2013 European Karate Championships">
        2013 European Karate Championships
       </a>
       and will be the host of 4 matches in the
       <a href="/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2020" title="UEFA Euro 2020">
        UEFA Euro 2020
       </a>
       , which will be held in the 67,889-seat new
       <a href="/wiki/Multi-purpose_stadium" title="Multi-purpose stadium">
        multi-purpose
       </a>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/New_Pusk%C3%A1s_Ferenc_Stadium" title="New Puskás Ferenc Stadium">
        Puskás Ferenc Stadium
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_Grand_Prix" title="Hungarian Grand Prix">
        Hungarian Grand Prix
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Formula_One" title="Formula One">
        Formula One
       </a>
       has been held at the
       <a href="/wiki/Hungaroring" title="Hungaroring">
        Hungaroring
       </a>
       just outside
       <a href="/wiki/Budapest" title="Budapest">
        Budapest
       </a>
       , which circuit has
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/FIA" title="FIA">
        FIA
       </a>
       Grade 1 license.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-218">
        <a href="#cite_note-218">
         [218]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Since 1986, the race has been a round of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/FIA" title="FIA">
        FIA
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Formula_One" title="Formula One">
        Formula One
       </a>
       World Championship. At the
       <a href="/wiki/2013_Hungarian_Grand_Prix" title="2013 Hungarian Grand Prix">
        2013 Hungarian Grand Prix
       </a>
       , it was confirmed that Hungary will continue to host a Formula 1 race until 2021.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-219">
        <a href="#cite_note-219">
         [219]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The track was completely resurfaced for the first time in early 2016, and it was announced the Grand Prix's deal was extended for a further 5 years, until 2026.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-220">
        <a href="#cite_note-220">
         [220]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Chess" title="Chess">
        Chess
       </a>
       is also a popular and successful sport in Hungary, the Hungarian players are the 10th most powerful overall on the ranking of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/World_Chess_Federation" title="World Chess Federation">
        World Chess Federation
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-221">
        <a href="#cite_note-221">
         [221]
        </a>
       </sup>
       There are about 54
       <a href="/wiki/Grandmaster_(chess)" title="Grandmaster (chess)">
        Grandmasters
       </a>
       and 118
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/International_Masters" title="International Masters">
        International Masters
       </a>
       in Hungary, which is more than in
       <a href="/wiki/France" title="France">
        France
       </a>
       or
       <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom" title="United Kingdom">
        United Kingdom
       </a>
       . World top junior player is the Hungarian
       <a href="/wiki/Rich%C3%A1rd_Rapport" title="Richárd Rapport">
        Richárd Rapport
       </a>
       currently on the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/FIDE_World_Rankings" title="FIDE World Rankings">
        FIDE World Rankings
       </a>
       , while
       <a href="/wiki/Judit_Polg%C3%A1r" title="Judit Polgár">
        Judit Polgár
       </a>
       generally considered the
       <a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_chess#Strength" title="Glossary of chess">
        strongest
       </a>
       female chess player of all time. Some of the world's best
       <a href="/wiki/Sabre_(fencing)" title="Sabre (fencing)">
        sabre
       </a>
       athletes have historically also hailed from Hungary,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-222">
        <a href="#cite_note-222">
         [222]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-223">
        <a href="#cite_note-223">
         [223]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and in 2009, the Hungarian national ice hockey team qualified for their first
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/IIHF_World_Championships" title="IIHF World Championships">
        IIHF World Championship
       </a>
       , in 2015, they qualified for their second World Championship in the top division.
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Football">
        Football
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hungary&amp;action=edit&amp;section=40" title="Edit section: Football">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/Football_in_Hungary" title="Football in Hungary">
        Football in Hungary
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Hungary has won three Olympic football titles, finished runners-up in the
       <a href="/wiki/1938_FIFA_World_Cup" title="1938 FIFA World Cup">
        1938
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/1954_FIFA_World_Cup" title="1954 FIFA World Cup">
        1954 FIFA World Cups
       </a>
       , and third in the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/1964_UEFA_European_Football_Championship" title="1964 UEFA European Football Championship">
        1964 UEFA European Football Championship
       </a>
       . Hungary revolutionized the sport in the 1950s, laying the tactical fundamentals of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Total_football" title="Total football">
        total football
       </a>
       and dominating international football with the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Magical_Magyars" title="Magical Magyars">
        <i>
         Aranycsapat
        </i>
       </a>
       ("Golden Team"), which included
       <a href="/wiki/Ferenc_Pusk%C3%A1s" title="Ferenc Puskás">
        Ferenc Puskás
       </a>
       , top goalscorer of the 20th century,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FIFA_benefit_224-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FIFA_benefit-224">
         [224]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Spanish_obit_225-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Spanish_obit-225">
         [225]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Puskás_auction_226-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Puskás_auction-226">
         [226]
        </a>
       </sup>
       to whom FIFA dedicated
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-227">
        <a href="#cite_note-227">
         [227]
        </a>
       </sup>
       its newest award, the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/FIFA_Ferenc_Pusk%C3%A1s_Award" title="FIFA Ferenc Puskás Award">
        Puskás Award
       </a>
       . The side of that era has the second
       <a href="/wiki/World_Football_Elo_Ratings#All-time_highest_ratings" title="World Football Elo Ratings">
        all-time highest Football Elo Ranking in the world
       </a>
       , with 2166, and one of the longest undefeated runs in football history, remaining unbeaten in 31 games spanning more than four years.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-228">
        <a href="#cite_note-228">
         [228]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The post-golden age decades saw a gradually weakening Hungary, though recently there is renewal in all aspects. The Hungarian Children's Football Federation was founded in 2008, as youth development thrives. For the first time in Hungarian football's history, they hosted the
       <a href="/wiki/2010_UEFA_Futsal_Championship" title="2010 UEFA Futsal Championship">
        2010 UEFA Futsal Championship
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Budapest" title="Budapest">
        Budapest
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Debrecen" title="Debrecen">
        Debrecen
       </a>
       , the first time the
       <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_Football_Federation" title="Hungarian Football Federation">
        MLSZ
       </a>
       staged a
       <a href="/wiki/UEFA" title="UEFA">
        UEFA
       </a>
       finals tournament. Also, the national teams have produced some surprise successes such as beating
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Euro_2004" title="Euro 2004">
        Euro 2004
       </a>
       winner
       <a href="/wiki/Greece_national_football_team" title="Greece national football team">
        Greece
       </a>
       3–2
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-229">
        <a href="#cite_note-229">
         [229]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/2006_FIFA_World_Cup" title="2006 FIFA World Cup">
        2006 FIFA World Cup
       </a>
       winner
       <a href="/wiki/Italy_national_football_team" title="Italy national football team">
        Italy
       </a>
       3–1.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-230">
        <a href="#cite_note-230">
         [230]
        </a>
       </sup>
       During
       <a href="/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2016" title="UEFA Euro 2016">
        UEFA Euro 2016
       </a>
       Hungary won
       <a href="/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2016_Group_F" title="UEFA Euro 2016 Group F">
        Group F
       </a>
       and were eventually defeated in the round of 16.
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">

          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation web">
            <a class="external text" href="http://www.ksh.hu/nepszamlalas/tablak_teruleti_00" rel="nofollow">
             "Hungarian census 2011 / Országos adatok (National data) / 1.1.4.2. A népesség nyelvismeret és nemek szerint (population by spoken language), 1.1.6.1 A népesség anyanyelv, nemzetiség és nemek szerint (population by mother tongue and ethnicity), 2.1.7.1 A népesség vallás, felekezet, és fontosabb demográfiai ismérvek szerint (population by religion, denomination and main demographical indicators) (Hungarian)"
            </a>

            </i>
            <span class="reference-accessdate">

             <span class="nowrap">

            </span>
            .
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Ksh.hu&amp;rft.atitle=Hungarian+census+2011+%2F+Orsz%C3%A1gos+adatok+%28National+data%29+%2F+1.1.4.2.+A+n%C3%A9pess%C3%A9g+nyelvismeret+%C3%A9s+nemek+szerint+%28population+by+spoken+language%29%2C+1.1.6.1+A+n%C3%A9pess%C3%A9g+anyanyelv%2C+nemzetis%C3%A9g+%C3%A9s+nemek+szerint+%28population+by+mother+tongue+and+ethnicity%29%2C+2.1.7.1+A+n%C3%A9pess%C3%A9g+vall%C3%A1s%2C+felekezet%2C+%C3%A9s+fontosabb+demogr%C3%A1fiai+ism%C3%A9rvek+szerint+%28population+by+religion%2C+denomination+and+main+demographical+indicators%29+%28Hungarian%29&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.ksh.hu%2Fnepszamlalas%2Ftablak_teruleti_00&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHungary">

          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation encyclopaedia">
            <a class="external text" href="http://www.encyclopedia.com/doc/1E1-TrianonTr.html" rel="nofollow">

            .
            <i>

         <li id="cite_note-Montgomery-23">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-Montgomery_23-0">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">

         <li id="cite_note-Rao,_B._V._2006-25">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-Rao,_B._V._2006_25-0">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           It was governed by the
           <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_Socialist_Workers%27_Party" title="Hungarian Socialist Workers' Party">
            Socialist Workers' Party
           </a>
           , which was under the influence of the
           <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">
            Soviet Union
           </a>
           . – Rao, B. V. (2006),
           <i>
            History of Modern Europe Ad 1789–2002: A.D. 1789–2002
           </i>
           , Sterling Publishers Pvt. Ltd.
          </span>

           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=The+Avar+Khaganate&amp;rft.pub=Allempires.com&amp;rft.date=2007-05-31&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.allempires.com%2Farticle%2Findex.php%3Fq%3DThe_Avar_Khaganate&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHungary">
            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>

             ^

           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           Peter B. Golden,
           <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?ei=VOVrTp3XLIGd-waJvvjeBA&amp;ct=result&amp;id=K2ppAAAAMAAJ&amp;dq=Nomads+and+their+neighbours+in+the+Russian+steppe%3A+Turks%2C+Khazars+and+Qipchaqs&amp;q=%22western+Tourkia%22#search_anchor" rel="nofollow">
            Nomads and their neighbours in the Russian steppe: Turks, Khazars and Qipchaqs
           </a>
           , Ashgate/Variorum, 2003. "Tenth-century Byzantine sources, speaking in cultural more than ethnic terms, acknowledged a wide zone of diffusion by referring to the Khazar lands as 'Eastern Tourkia' and Hungary as 'Western Tourkia.'" Carter Vaughn Findley,
           <a class="external text" href="http://www.fatih.edu/~ayasar/HIST388/The%20Turks%20in%20World%20History.pdf" rel="nofollow">

           </a>

           5 February 2016 at the
           <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">

           <i>
            Archivum Eurasiae Medii Aevi
           </i>
           2 (1982), 37–76.

         <li id="cite_note-HR-HU-Heka-70">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-HR-HU-Heka_70-0">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation journal">
            Ladislav Heka (October 2008).
            <a class="external text" href="http://hrcak.srce.hr/index.php?show=clanak&amp;id_clanak_jezik=68144" rel="nofollow">
             "Hrvatsko-ugarski odnosi od sredinjega vijeka do nagodbe iz 1868. s posebnim osvrtom na pitanja Slavonije"
            </a>
            [Croatian-Hungarian relations from the Middle Ages to the Compromise of 1868, with a special survey of the Slavonian issue].
            <i>
             Scrinia Slavonica
            </i>
            (in Croatian). Hrvatski institut za povijest – Podružnica za povijest Slavonije, Srijema i Baranje.
            <b>
             8
            </b>
            (1): 152–173.
            <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Serial_Number" title="International Standard Serial Number">
             ISSN
            </a>

          <span class="reference-text">
           François Bugnion, International Committee of the Red Cross, The International Committee of the Red Cross and the protection of war victims, Macmillan Education, 2003
           <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=6K9IAAAAYAAJ&amp;q=signed+general+armistice+in+Padua+on+3+November+1918&amp;dq=signed+general+armistice+in+Padua+on+3+November+1918&amp;hl=en&amp;ei=BqLQTKvjGYn0sgbnq7DNCA&amp;sa=X&amp;oi=book_result&amp;ct=result&amp;resnum=2&amp;ved=0CC8Q6AEwAQ" rel="nofollow">
            Google Books
           </a>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-93">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-93">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           Molnar, A Concise History of Hungary, p. 262
           <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=y0g4YEp7ZrsC&amp;pg=PA262&amp;dq=found+themselves+separated+from+their+motherland&amp;ei=UI13Sa3bEouYMsCR-L4E" rel="nofollow">
            online
           </a>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-94">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-94">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           Richard C. Frucht, Eastern Europe: An Introduction to the People, Lands, and Culture p. 359–360
           <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=lVBB1a0rC70C&amp;pg=RA1-PA360&amp;dq=found+themselves+separated+from+their+motherland&amp;ei=UI13Sa3bEouYMsCR-L4E#PRA1-PA359,M1" rel="nofollow">
            online
           </a>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-J._Lee_Ready_1995_page_130-95">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           ^
           <a href="#cite_ref-J._Lee_Ready_1995_page_130_95-0">
            <sup>
             <i>
              <b>
               a
              </b>
             </i>
            </sup>
           </a>
           <a href="#cite_ref-J._Lee_Ready_1995_page_130_95-1">
            <sup>
             <i>
              <b>
               b
              </b>
             </i>
            </sup>
           </a>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           J. Lee Ready (1995),
           <i>
            World War Two. Nation by Nation
           </i>
           , London, Cassell, page 130.
           <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">
            ISBN
           </a>
           <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/1-85409-290-1" title="Special:BookSources/1-85409-290-1">
            1-85409-290-1
           </a>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-bbc-no-warning-to-hungary-jews-96">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-bbc-no-warning-to-hungary-jews_96-0">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation web">
            Mike Thomson (13 November 2012).
            <a class="external text" href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-20267659" rel="nofollow">
             "Could the BBC have done more to help Hungarian Jews?"
            </a>
            . BBC (British broadcasting service).
            <q>
             the BBC broadcast every day, giving updates on the war, general news and opinion pieces on Hungarian politics. But among all these broadcasts, there were crucial things that were not being said, things that might have warned thousands of Hungarian Jews of the horrors to come in the event of a German occupation. A memo setting out policy for the BBC Hungarian Service in 1942 states: "We shouldn't mention the Jews at all." By 1943, the BBC Polish Service was broadcasting about the exterminations And yet his policy of silence on the Jews was followed right up until the German invasion in March 1944. After the tanks rolled in, the Hungarian Service did then broadcast warnings. But by then it was too late "Many Hungarian Jews who survived the deportations claimed that they had not been informed by their leaders, that no one had told them. But there's plenty of evidence that they could have known," said David Cesarani, Professor of History at Royal Holloway, University of London.
            </q>
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Could+the+BBC+have+done+more+to+help+Hungarian+Jews%3F&amp;rft.pub=BBC+%28British+broadcasting+service%29&amp;rft.date=2012-11-13&amp;rft.au=Mike+Thomson&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.bbc.co.uk%2Fnews%2Fworld-europe-20267659&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHungary">
            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>

           <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=BB4NAQAAIAAJ&amp;pg=RA1-PA202&amp;dq=Czechoslovaks+slave+labour+Hungarians&amp;hl=en&amp;ei=eHjOTOc0ho-zBpue-fcE&amp;sa=X&amp;oi=book_result&amp;ct=result&amp;resnum=1&amp;ved=0CCcQ6AEwADgK#v=onepage&amp;q&amp;f=false" rel="nofollow">

         <li id="cite_note-108">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-108">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           Alfred J. Rieber, Forced migration in Central and Eastern Europe, 1939–1950, Routledge, 2000, p. 50
           <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=it0-Zi2nEX0C&amp;pg=PA90&amp;dq=Czechoslovaks+slave+labour+Hungarians&amp;hl=en&amp;ei=infOTMHQFMLBswbE0eSWCA&amp;sa=X&amp;oi=book_result&amp;ct=result&amp;resnum=2&amp;ved=0CC0Q6AEwAQ#v=onepage&amp;q&amp;f=false" rel="nofollow">
            Google Books
           </a>
           – "A presidential decree imposing an obligation on individuals not engaged in useful work to accept jobs served as the basis for this action. As a result, according to documentation in the ministry of foreign affairs of the USSR, approximately 50,000 Hungarians were sent to work in factories and agricultural enterprises in the Czech Republic."

             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation news">
            Stolz, Joëlle (11 January 2011).
            <a class="external text" href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/jan/11/hungary-birth-rate-women-stolz" rel="nofollow">
             "Hungarian government sends women home to make babies"
            </a>

           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Bbj.hu&amp;rft.atitle=Dental+Tourism+Development+clinics+turnover+up+19%25&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.bbj.hu%2Fbusiness%2Fdental-tourism-development-clinics-turnover-up-19percent_69020&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHungary">

           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Oefi.hu&amp;rft.atitle=Eg%C3%A9szs%C3%A9gjelent%C3%A9s+2016&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.oefi.hu%2Folef%2FOLEF2003%2FJelentesek%2FKronikusBbetegsegekOLEF2003.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHungary">

         <li id="cite_note-197">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">

             ^

           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">

           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Mno.hu&amp;rft.atitle=Egy+%C3%A9v+alatt+kilenc+sz%C3%A1zal%C3%A9kkal+cs%C3%B6kkent+a+doh%C3%A1nyosok+sz%C3%A1ma&amp;rft.date=2013-11-19&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fmno.hu%2Fbelfold%2Fegy-ev-alatt-kilenc-szazalekkal-csokkent-a-dohanyosok-szama-1196229&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHungary">

         <li id="cite_note-198">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-198">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation web">
            <a class="external text" href="http://www.bbj.hu/economy/govt-allocates-huf-450-mln-to-company-facilitating-tobacco-sales-monopoly_64136" rel="nofollow">

            </a>

            </i>

             </span>

            </span>

           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Bbj.hu&amp;rft.atitle=Govt+allocates+HUF+450+mln+to+company+facilitating+tobacco+sales+monopoly&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.bbj.hu%2Feconomy%2Fgovt-allocates-huf-450-mln-to-company-facilitating-tobacco-sales-monopoly_64136&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHungary">
            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-199">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-199">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation web">
            <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20101214123942/http://budapestcorner.com/index.php/flats/general-information" rel="nofollow">
             "General information on various student flats and building types in Budapest"
            </a>
            . Budapest Corner. Archived from
            <a class="external text" href="http://budapestcorner.com/index.php/flats/general-information" rel="nofollow">
             the original
            </a>
            on 14 December 2010
            <span class="reference-accessdate">
             . Retrieved
             <span class="nowrap">
              11 December
             </span>
             2010
            </span>
            .
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=General+information+on+various+student+flats+and+building+types+in+Budapest&amp;rft.pub=Budapest+Corner&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fbudapestcorner.com%2Findex.php%2Fflats%2Fgeneral-information&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHungary">
            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-200">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-200">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <a class="external text" href="http://mek.oszk.hu/02100/02172/html/index.html" rel="nofollow">
            Szabolcsi
           </a>
           Although the Hungarian upper class has long had cultural and political connections with the rest of Europe, leading to an influx of European musical ideas, the rural peasants maintained their own traditions such that by the end of the 19th century Hungarian composers could draw on rural peasant music to (re)create a Hungarian classical style. For example,
           <a href="/wiki/B%C3%A9la_Bart%C3%B3k" title="Béla Bartók">
            Béla Bartók
           </a>
           and
           <a href="/wiki/Zolt%C3%A1n_Kod%C3%A1ly" title="Zoltán Kodály">
            Zoltán Kodály
           </a>
           , two of Hungary's most famous composers, are known for using folk themes in their own music.
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-201">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-201">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           Szalipszki, p. 12
           <br/>
           Refers to the country as "widely considered" to be a "home of music".
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-Broughton-202">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-Broughton_202-0">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           Broughton, pp. 159–167
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-203">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-203">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           Szabolcsi,
           <i>
            The Specific Conditions of Hungarian Musical Development
           </i>
           <br/>
           "Every experiment, made from Hungarian antecedents and on Hungarian soil, to create a conscious musical culture (music written by composers, as different from folk music), had instinctively or consciously striven to develop widely and universally the musical world of the folk song. Folk poetry and folk music were deeply embedded in the collective Hungarian people's culture, and this unity did not cease to be effective even when it was given from and expression by individual creative artists, performers and poets."
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-Szabolcsi-204">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-Szabolcsi_204-0">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation web">
            <a class="external text" href="http://mek.oszk.hu/02100/02172/html/index.html" rel="nofollow">
             "Szabolcsi"
            </a>
            . Mek.oszk.hu
            <span class="reference-accessdate">
             . Retrieved
             <span class="nowrap">
              20 September
             </span>
             2009
            </span>
            .
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Szabolcsi&amp;rft.pub=Mek.oszk.hu&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fmek.oszk.hu%2F02100%2F02172%2Fhtml%2Findex.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHungary">
            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-205">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-205">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation web">
            <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20080620004145/http://www.sulinet.hu/tart/fcikk/Kjc/0/23144/1" rel="nofollow">
             "Sulinet: Magyar növény-e a paprika?"
            </a>
            . Sulinet.hu. Archived from
            <a class="external text" href="http://www.sulinet.hu/tart/fcikk/Kjc/0/23144/1" rel="nofollow">
             the original
            </a>
            on 20 June 2008
            <span class="reference-accessdate">
             . Retrieved
             <span class="nowrap">
              21 November
             </span>
             2008
            </span>
            .
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Sulinet%3A+Magyar+n%C3%B6v%C3%A9ny-e+a+paprika%3F&amp;rft.pub=Sulinet.hu&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.sulinet.hu%2Ftart%2Ffcikk%2FKjc%2F0%2F23144%2F1&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHungary">
            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-206">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-206">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           This is the world-famous sweet, topaz-colored wine known throughout the English-speaking world as
           <b>
            Tokay
           </b>
           . “A rich, sweet, moderately strong wine of a topaz color, produced in the vicinity of Tokay, in Hungary; also, a similar wine produced elsewhere.”
           <i>
            Webster’s New International Dictionary of the English Language
           </i>
           (Springfield, Mass.: G.&amp;C. Merriam, 1913). See
           <i>
            Tokay
           </i>
           at page 2166.
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-207">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-207">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation web">
            <a class="external text" href="http://eger.hu/hu/hirek/vezeto-hirek/c/egri-bikaver-hungarikum-lett-a-voros-cuvee-16832" rel="nofollow">
             "EGRI BIKAVÉR – HUNGARIKUM LETT A VÖRÖS CUVÉE"
            </a>
            . Eger.hu.
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=EGRI+BIKAV%C3%89R+%E2%80%93+HUNGARIKUM+LETT+A+V%C3%96R%C3%96S+CUV%C3%89E&amp;rft.pub=Eger.hu&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Feger.hu%2Fhu%2Fhirek%2Fvezeto-hirek%2Fc%2Fegri-bikaver-hungarikum-lett-a-voros-cuvee-16832&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHungary">
            <span style="display:none;">

         <li id="cite_note-royal_tokaji-208">

           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=TRUE+HERITAGE+%E2%80%93+Vinum+Regum%2C+Rex+Vinorum+%E2%80%93+Wine+of+Kings%2C+King+of+Wines&amp;rft.pub=The+Royal+Tokaji+Wine+Company%2C+2013&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.royal-tokaji.com%2Fwine_of_kings.php&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHungary">

         <li id="cite_note-220">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-220">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation web">
            <a class="external text" href="http://hungaroring.hu/hu/hirek/aszfaltavato-a-hungaroringen" rel="nofollow">
             "Aszfaltavató a Hungaroringen"
            </a>
            (in Hungarian).
            <a href="/wiki/Hungaroring" title="Hungaroring">
             Hungaroring
            </a>
            . 14 April 2016
            <span class="reference-accessdate">
             . Retrieved
             <span class="nowrap">
              15 April
             </span>
             2016
            </span>
            .
            <q>
             A Magyar Nagydíj szerződését újabb öt évvel meghosszabbítottuk, ami azt jelenti, hogy a futamunknak 2026-ig helye van a Formula–1-es versenynaptárban." Translates as "We have extended the Hungarian Grand Prix's contract for a further 5 years, which means that our race has a place on the F1 calendar until 2026.
            </q>

           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Guardian&amp;rft.atitle=Lineker+tees+up+another+nice+little+earner&amp;rft.date=2005-10-13&amp;rft.aulast=Mackay&amp;rft.aufirst=Duncan&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fsport.guardian.co.uk%2Fgolf%2Fstory%2F0%2C10069%2C1590809%2C00.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHungary">
            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-227">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>

            </a>

      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="External_links">
        External links
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hungary&amp;action=edit&amp;section=43" title="Edit section: External links">
         edit
        </a>

         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>

             <tr>
              <td class="navbox-abovebelow" colspan="3" style="text-align:left;">
               <div>
                <div class="plainlist">
                 <ul>
                  <li>
                   <sup>
                    1
                   </sup>
                   <a href="/wiki/Island#Oceanic_islands" title="Island">
                    Oceanic islands
                   </a>
                   within the vicinity of Europe are usually grouped with the continent even though they are not situated on its continental shelf.
                  </li>
                  <li>
                   <sup>
                    2
                   </sup>
                   Some countries completely outside the conventional geographical boundaries of Europe are commonly associated with the continent due to ethnological links.
                  </li>
                 </ul>
                </div>
               </div>
              </td>
             </tr>

                 </li>

                  <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Council_of_Europe&amp;action=edit">
                   <abbr style="background:rgb(0, 51, 153);color:white;;;background:none transparent;border:none;-moz-box-shadow:none;-webkit-box-shadow:none;box-shadow:none;" title="Edit this template">
                    e
                   </abbr>
                  </a>
                 </li>
                </ul>
               </div>
               <div id="23px&amp;#124;border_&amp;#124;alt=&amp;#124;link=_Council_of_Europe" style="font-size:114%;margin:0 4em">
                <span class="flagicon">
                 <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="540" data-file-width="810" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Flag_of_Europe.svg/23px-Flag_of_Europe.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Flag_of_Europe.svg/35px-Flag_of_Europe.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Flag_of_Europe.svg/46px-Flag_of_Europe.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>
                </span>
                <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Europe" title="Council of Europe">
                 <span style="color:white;">
                  Council of Europe

                </a>

                  </a>
                 </li>

                   3rd (1999)
                  </a>

                 <li>

               </div>
              </td>

                  </a>
                  , participates as "Hong Kong, China" and "Macao China".

                  </a>

              <td class="navbox-list navbox-odd" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px">

                  </a>

                  </a>

                  <a href="/wiki/Buda_Castle" title="Buda Castle">

                  </a>

                  </a>

                 </li>

                   Hortobágy National Park
                  </a>

                   <small>

                   </small>
                  </sup>

                  </a>

                 </li>

                   Tokaj Wine Region Historic Cultural Landscape
                  </a>
                 </li>

            <img alt="Europe green light.png" data-file-height="226" data-file-width="260" height="21" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/Europe_green_light.png/24px-Europe_green_light.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/Europe_green_light.png/36px-Europe_green_light.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/Europe_green_light.png/48px-Europe_green_light.png 2x" width="24"/>
           </a>
          </span>
          <a href="/wiki/Portal:Europe" title="Portal:Europe">
           Europe portal
          </a>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li style="display:inline">
         <span style="display:inline-block;white-space:nowrap">
          <span style="margin:0 0.5em">
           <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Terra.png">

           </a>
